If you like nature you should definitely go there. It is not very big and also it looks like it hasn't been taken care of for a while. The entrance is a little hard to find - it is on the side.
Visited twice and both times. A lovely park a d appeared well kept - enjoyed the walk around in the heat wave ! Free entry and worth a visit - a nice pond with loads of wildlife evident.
It is very interesting garden.....beautiful. The only problem can be some misbehaviour of students! I dont like what they do to all the parks here in Montpellier. But the place could be just heaven!

Oh, the potential in this nice old urban garden! And the neglect! If it wasn't so hot in this part of the world (and if we didn't love where we live) I would have moved to Montpelier to help them work on this garden! Full of frogs and other little water critters, and nice old

The herb garden of Montpellier University is famous for being the oldest and most extensive in Europe alongside its even more famous medical school. Tram lines are being inserted into the road that cuts the gardens from the medical school, which at the present is unfortunate,

The Jardin des Plantes is a lovely place to chill out particularly in the Spring or summer where the flowers are in bloom. Its peaceful most of the time but obviously gets quite busy in peak tourist season.

The botanical garden is free, but is disappointing on a number of counts. First, it is not well kept, with lots of weeds left to grow freely everywhere. Second, there are interesting looking greenhouses of cacti and succulents, but they are closed to the public (so who enjoys

We have a botanical garden owned by the university in the town where I live so I must say the part of the gardens we visited was a bit disappointing. I do not know the condition of the parts we did not visit, but at least part of the garden is in serious need of work. We did

Quite a bit was closed, but the open bits were also in need of more work and TLC - as it belongs to the university how about incentivising volunteering. Extensively used - lots of people picnicing etc despite notices to the contrary

I love the Great Expectations' "Miss Haversham" style of the gardens... The peace and quiet in central Montpellier is soul-restoring... There is no better place for a quiet stroll, or afternoon spent propped against a tree reading or sketching...
Dark and sober in its wintry cloak the birds dared sing on the bright dawn before spring. Return to a garden when it bursts back into life. Well located and interesting, I will return
We went to the gardens, but all the greenhouses were clñosed, some parts we not accesable or unde repair. I think it was just not the right time to go....
I was a bit disappointed honestly.. it's not that pretty and very small. I would visit something else in Montpellier, lots of great monuments to choose from!
I went here one lunchtime to find somewhere to sit and eat my lunch. Wasn't expecting a lot but I was pleasantly surprised. Very pretty and you forget you're in a city!

In case you want a break from the busy city, the Botanical Garden, is a nice place to relax your mind. It is actually the oldest Botanical Garden in France, created by Professor Pierre Richer de Belleval in 1593 after an order from King Henri IV. In fact, the garden served as an
Such a tranquil space! We loved the huge greenhouse with cacti in it, and the herb garden was delightful.

The garden is being updated presently by Montpellier University and they're doing a fantastic job. Even in late October, there was still plenty of colour. The middle section is closed at present, but around the edge are many varieties of trees, all labelled, including a sequoia.

While as others have mentioned, it is a little run down, there are sections currently closed off and (I assume) being fixed up. Nevertheless, I didn't really mind - not all gardens need to be pristine and manicured! Bring a book, bring the kids or just bring yourself for a

as a very old botanical garden from 1789 it shows the lack of $$ and care over the past period of quite a few years. Run down, and in urgent need of $$ and some tender loving care. While some work is now being done, lots more needed. Orangery [ very famous ] is awful, too
A good collection of plants. Pretty, Calm. Part being renovated. Busy at weekends but quiet in the week. Went twice. Spot the frogs in the pond
A large part of the garden is closed for renovation, the rest has a run down air but quiet pleasant nonetheless. Goo place for relaxation and quiet contemplation.
Mix of new and old garden design. Originally the garden for the Ecole de Medicine opposite. Nice place to wander and relax in away from the City.

We spent a pleasant 45 minutes exploring the gardens and taking pictures. You do have to go in the entrance along Boulevard Henri IV as we walked the opposite direction by mistake and, though we found other gates, they were all locked. Very relaxing.
Kind of smelly. Got the impression that nearby university students just use this place to smoke weed.
The botanical gardens make for a great escape from the pandaemonium of the city and there are lots of excellent cafes and bistros nearby.

This is an ideal antidote to the worthwhile, but somewhat sombre and oppressive atmosphere of the nearby cathedral. The garden has a superb hothouse and a pleasingly informal layout which is a welcome relief from the tree lined open deserts of the typical Parisian type space,

We did not have as long here as I would have liked, so had to rush a bit; but I found it delightful. It is part of the university, and I think it is being restored in some parts, so I am not sure we had access to the full area. There are some beautiful formal layouts in the
If you have an hour and you don't know how to spend it - go to the jardin des plantes and walk the trails Nostradamus walked. Beautifull, romantic! You might meet the wild cats there too :)

We went to visit the gardens during the regular business hours but they were closed. There was not indication as to why this was the case. We tried a second time but the gates were still locked.....unfortunate.
A work in progress but a lovely and peaceful spot nevertheless. Thought there would be more colour. Conservatory of cacti was closed.
These are lovely gardens, the local people appear to eat lunch there. They are very interesting as it specializes in plants with medical uses.

Loved this place! Loved that it's so natural, not one of these fancy botanical gardens but really a keeper of natural environment. Free entrance too. Was told one couldn't picnic there, and so said the signs, so I had my lunch in the park at L'Arc de Triomphe, before heading
Hidden down away from the main town this park is lovely, has a great collection of plants and trees as well as a cactus greenhouse. Also great to get away from the hustle and bustle of the main town

Walking through the Jardin de Plants i found a lot of emotions with myself. Moments of: stunning, amazing, romance, disbelieve, loving and seeing myself and my work. This garden is a joy for all persons in the world....nature lovers, families with children, older people.
It is fascinating and offers a glimpse into what it was like years ago. It is beautiful and quiet and a great place to find a bench and enjoy the scenery or read a book

I agree with the reviews that point out how neglected and under-watered the plants are. It is a pity to see plants expected to "fend for themselves" instead of receiving proper care. This is a historical medicinal garden that dates back centuries. What a treasure it could be

We’ve been here before, a couple of times in the last 10 years. Each time, we hoped that there would be an improvement. Sadly, this isn’t the case… The Jardin seems to be the joint responsibility of the University and the Ville and though there have been some changes, the same

A great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. So pleasant to walk through the gardens which are pretty and peaceful. There's no entry fee and often used by the locals at lunchtime. Definitely worth a visit.

We loved spending a few hours strolling through the gardens, it was great to escape the hustle and noise of the city without having to travel too far. It was very pretty and peaceful. Free entry and not a soul around to disturb. Well worth a visit. The locals seem to use it as a

A bit of a disappointment. Parts of it were being rebuilt and the rest seemed a little neglected. Bushes not trimmed for instance. It's a pleasant enough afternoon stroll but not the best Jardin des Plantes I've been to.

The garden has been there since the time of Henry IV which is quite some time and even though it will never rival the more formal gardens of the great palaces this is a place of gentle beauty which is also a centre for botanical/medical research - prepare not to be blown away
We thoroughly enjoyed our afternoon here. The gardens are less formal than others but extensive. They close around 5:30 pm so plan accordingly.
I've visited here twice, the first time it was a bit dry and I didn't love it. The second time it was after a bit of rain and the plants were alive again. It was nice when everything is alive.

Set in about ten acres, these fine botanical gardens were set up for the study of medicinal plants and the propagation of seeds for exchange with other gardens from around the world. Some parts are formal with parterres and cool rows of cypress trees whilst others show more
Visited in September and saw Lotus pods growing , frogs jumping on lily pads and a thick grove of bamboo. Will revisit in spring .

I think it's probably the best park in Montpellier, but that's not saying a lot because there isn't exactly a lot of choice! Don't expect to lie on the grass with a picnic, it's more of a place to walk along paths talking or to sit on a bench and read a book. There are a wide

Gardeners standing around chatting doing no work for over 45 minutes was our first impression - and that isn't great. Lots of the interesting parts of the grounds were fenced off - under planting - or something or other - but in other climes it would have been open to wander
Great botanical gardens in the centre of the city Interesting specimens It was totally free An oasis of calm

This was the garden of medical research for the university but it has much more than medicinal herbs. Lots of interesting palms, but it was no longer the season for flowers and the famed Ginko trees were closed to the public. But you can spend a pleasant hour wandering.

As newcomers to the city, we were looking for a place to escape to, away from the urban, without venturing out too far - and we found it. The Jardin des plantes offered us a lovely walk through a small forest of various species, a beautiful bamboo forest to observe and a great

The Jardin des Plantes is a great place to go if you are visiting Montpellier. There are lots of different places to wander in this garden - a lake, tree-lined paths, a bamboo forest, and more. I have been several times and I don't think I have visited every part of it! It is

These are very pleasant gardens with some welcome shade in the summer. Unfortunately some of the gardens were closed for maintenance when I visited but overall they were lovely. I would certainly include a visit as you walk around Montpellier.
nice place to laze and cool in the shade. Don't forget to put your head in the college of Pharmacy. 1 hour is enough to do the circle but it's very beautiful

Still well maintained these botannical gardens were the first in Europe established by the faculty of medicine in Montpellier. I have grown a Ginko Biloba from a (stolen) fruit from the first Ginko ever grown in France!!
If you like gardens these are worth a visit, really lovely to wander around with some nice features.
We hope to walk around but it was too hot. We sat and had a rest so did not see as much as we had hoped.

I had high hopes for the oldest botanical garden in Europe and was so disappointed! The collection is sadly neglected, likely because they don't charge an entry fee and so likely can't afford the labor required to care for a botanical garden. The structure is all there, but

We were disappointed with the Jardins. They were not very well kept, closed before midday and nearly half were under renovation. Not worth the visit. The Place Royale 200 metres further up at the top of the hill were infinitely better.
A bit disappointing - in fairness it is being renovated but I felt the whole area was neglected and did not live up to what I thought it would be. Not worth the time if time is short

A nice and quiet walk in the middle of the city close to the Cathedral and the faculty of medicine. The greenhiouses are being restaured and worth seeing. And you have the impression that - walking next to the statues - you are experiencing a promenade in another century
Within easy walk of the old city, the Jardin des Plantes is a good, quiet place to sit down and relax.

Montpellier is hot in the summer - and this is a spot of green just at the edge of the old city walls. Walk it from the Comédie in 10 minutes. Once there, you'll find ... plants! The Jardins used to be part of the ancient medical school. Many famous people have passed through
Great place with some lovely scenery. Some more explanation about the plants etc would have been appreciated but we still enjoyed our trip there. Great for a picnic!
This is a lovely garden filled with plants and beautiful flowers. There is loads of places to sit and take in the scent of the flowers. It is an oasis of peace and quiet. Just lovely

This is one of (if not the) oldest botanical gardens in France. I visit it weekly, and the changes are wonderful to see as the various plants bloom. There are the various plantings, but I like the pond with water lilies, koi, turtles and frogs. It is a quiet oasis in the heart

We were disappointed half the garden is cordoned off as its being renovated, but it is in sore need of some TLC so good thet they are doing it! A wonderful garden with ancient trees ruins and different habitats including a parterre, pine walk and huge lily pond. Watch out for

Sadly, many specimens were struggling for survival after an exceptionally hard frost as evidenced by the dead palm trees etc in other parts of the city. Whereas a park in Britain would have been a riot of colour at this time of the year, in fact the overall effect was drab.
Nothing much to see and what there is there is all falling into disrepair. I found it very depressing. I named it the Abandoned Gardens.
Established when Montpellier became a seat of medical learning. Has been a bit shabby but renovation on going

as i was enjoying my holidays in Montpellier, i heard people talking about "Jardin des plantes", and i decided to visit it in order to discover this famous place from close!! My surprise when i get there was verryy unexpected, its a really amazing place, where we can have a

As I walked on the street and peered into the garden, I thought that I would really enjoy it, but I was a bit disappointed (maybe because we went in March and not everything was in bloom yet?). The dead leaves from winter had not yet been cleared away and a large section of the
This is an oasis of calm based on an ancient "herb" garden dating back many centuries. In the center of the old city, yet just off the main tourist roads - it is worth a visit

This rare plant garden features medicinal plants and dates from the time of Henry IV. It is slowly being restored and a lovely place to wander and ponder. The conservatory was being restored when we visited and looks like it will be truly magnificent once completed.
I enjoyed walking around this park, very pleasant.

Jardin des Plantes was a nice place to visit. They had some nice plants to look at, but it doesn't look like a super well-maintained garden. However, the flowers that are blooming when you visit look nice, and there are some nice large trees to relax under. Definitely worth

It is not so much of an exhibition garden as a public park that has exotic plants. So it is a bit worn down and not exactly exciting. But it is a nice little oasis in the city and a good place to find shade and some peace and quiet.

This is a list of aquaria (public aquariums). For dolphinariums, see List of dolphinariums. For zoos, see List of zoos. For a list of defunct zoos and aquariums, see List of former zoos and aquariums.
Aquariums are facilities where animals are confined within tanks and displayed to the public, and in which they may also be bred. Such facilities include public aquariums, oceanariums, marine mammal parks, and dolphinariums.
According to Vancouver Aquarium there are over 200 aquaria worldwide.

The diverse nature of the aquarium was a surprise - there really is a lot to see! The quality of the facilities is high, and the tanks were clean and appropriate for the fish, large and small. Even a bonus space experience at the end! Great value for money.
Aquarium Mare Nostrum and planétarium Galilée are together the Planet Ocean Montpellier. It is located at the Odysseum.

A wet Saturday pr3dictably meant this popular attraction was mobbed with families and small children. They seemed to love it, especially the sharks and the simulated storm at sea, when they got to man the bridge. The handful of penguins cut a forlorn figure, looking phased by

Part of the Odyssium complex, this is a great place for the children to see sharks and Rays. They have a big tank about 15-20 metres deep with cinema style seating plus various observation windows and above water viewing. As a veteran Indian Ocean and Red Sea diver I had seen it

We had a fab day at Planet Ocean, there was plenty to look around and various events throughout the day such as penguin feeding etc. The staff were also very friendly. We were disappointed however to find that, whilst the aquarium was fab, the planetarium consisted of some

I think because I have seen the Monterey Bay Sea Aquarium, my opinion is biased. The ship was great! Because we moved a lot for my husband's work, I have been to many aquariums. This was the first time I had seen one with the Mediterranean Sea so that was very interesting. It

A combination of aquarium and planetarium, they have gone big on the watery side. A great collection of fish and the obligatory penguins, above all it is beautifully presented. Getting to the main viewing window with fish above and beneath you presents a genuinely hypnotic
I would say it’s bit expensive but it worth this. It is much better than a lot of others such aquariums.

Popped here to kill a couple of hours while my partner was working. It really is the best aquarium I have been to. With lots of wildlife on show from sharks to jelly fish to penguins. Big tanks full of lively fish and lots of unusual things to see. I loved it.

We bought tickets online (you’ll save a Euro or two off admission) and got access to the aquarium and planetarium. Wonderful collection of fish and marine life, large shark tank, definitely lots to see and do. After finishing the aquarium you continue into the space exhibit.

Wow what a brilliant aquarium! We are from Cheshire And this beats blue planet hands down- we can do that In less than an hour but this was fab! Our lowest score out if 10 for our family was 9! The quality of the fish and water was superb! The fact we did the planetarium was
Rainy Montpelier meant no beach visit for us. Luckily we were able to go to the aquarium and what a site. All the different sea life to see was amazing. Large aquarium here Def worth a visit

This is a great place to take kids - lots to see and do and many of the glass panels go right down to floor level so you don't have to keep lifting toddlers up! We actually went as a couple but passed almost 2 hours here. The restaurant isn't much to write home about but OK for
An amazing place for children of all ages and their parents. Lots of nice fish, jellyfish, rays, sharks, etc. Huge sharks!!! Children can touch seastars and sea urchins!

Much better than expected! Really nice aquarium with plenty to see. Takes a good 2 hours to get around everything. Also placed in an area with a good selection of bars and restaurants and a few other activities such a trampoline park and a cinema

Came her to break up 2 week holiday - both us and the kids loved it. We live near Brighton which has an aquarium but I thought this was much better. Had lunch at the nearby pirate restaurant - definitely an experience for the children! Thoroughly recommend.
This is a decent little aquarium, worth a visit if you have a hour or so to kill. It won't blow your socks off but the kids will be happy.

Visited with my 5 yr old son who loved the whole experience - as did his Dad. It's really well laid out and keeps ones attention throughout - we particularly loved the sharks, jelly fish, huge viewing tank and Ocean tanker simulator - Oh yeah and penguin feeding time. Our queue

We always like to visit aquariums where possible. This one was really very good. Highlights were the jellyfish tank and the ocean tank - lots of sharks and saw fish. There was also a ship in high seas simulator which was really very very cool. Everything was clean and well

We booked our visit online in conjunction with a visit to the planetarium (which is in the same building), we had a time slot of 3:30. When we arrived we were shocked to see a massive queue outside, it went way past the half-hour sign and curved around the outside of the

Go to the aquarium. Not the highest one in Europe but the best one for kids. We went with our almost 3-year old (bring your stroller along as there are lifts to the different areas) He had a blast watching the sharks, penguins, stingrays (no lifting needed), playing in the

Visited with family- age range of 6-80! Everyone enjoyed it. Very well laid out with lots of different areas including a ship at sea and an underwater craft. Areas are set out by region and you work your way around. Each area has its own different features. There is a massive
My husband and I always visited the aquarium in whichever city we are visiting. Aquarium Mare Nostrum was not the biggest, but they have good and interesting selection of sea life.
Great place for a rainy day in Montpellier- the kids enjoyed it. It is also convenient for disabled people. It is not huge but quite alright
it was a great experience and one of the best aquarium I've seen in the Mediterranean region. offer different activities for all ages.
Spent a fantastic afternoon at the Mare nostrum aquarium kids absolutely loved it.If your in the Montpillier area take the time to visit .
Whom every designed this is a creative genius. It is so varied, so so we ll done its just a great experience and by far the best aquarium I have been too
The aquarium features nice interactive exhibits for the children. For example, they can simulate being in the middle of a storm. Well worth a visit.

We visited this one the day before the Seaquarium at Grau du Roi. It has more types of fish and bigger (for ex the sharks and octopus) but it's a little pricey and not that many kids activities. But we spent a nice afternoon so I would note it 4.5 stars.the down part is that you
We don't think it's worth what it cost. It was nice and had a lot of different things to see, but 50 euro for 3 people is high. Kids over 10 are counted as adults. Overall a nice stop
You can see impressive sealife from all over the world with special effects. It is well worth visiting it.
Excellent value for euro 15.00. Ingenious utilisation of an old ship and an old submarine! Very effective explanation of the various weathers at sea!

We arrived here by tram and thought it would be interesting which to be fair it was! The visit consists of a film and then a commentary on the skies. We were given headsets which provided an English translation to the soundtrack of the film but the commentary is all in French
Great aquarium with lots to see and do and even a simulated trip on the high season which my kids loved to bits. Even better it being so quiet thanks to French school kids having gone back

I planned to send my husband there with our 6 year old and do some shopping but changed my mind and joined them. I did not regret it, the place features good choice of sea creatures and entertainment such as an imitation of a ship bridge during storm. We all had great fun!
This is a lot of fun and really impressive. The sharks are what sold me! 2 hours are needed. Then have lunch next door.

Came here with a 3 & 6 year old, both loved it. Cost around 40 euros for us to visit. Giant tank full of sharks, rays and other interesting sea life was the highlight. Lots of other smaller tanks with jellyfish, eels and tons more. There was also a simulator that put you on the

The aquarium is fun to visit! Lot's of beautiful fishes to look at. Also, the place is quite cool, so i recommend visiting it in the hottest hours of the day to get some refreshment. It also has some small attractions which are also entertaining.

The aquarium was very nice and just good size for little kids. The ship-in-a-storm simulator was great as well as the spot where you were able to touch the fish too. The aisles were wide enough so it didn't get too crowded and the kids got to see all they wanted.

The aquarium is very nice. You can easily spend 2 hours with your children. You have a snack bar inside where you can get sodas, beer or sandwiches. Prices r quite expensive... The good thing is that the aquarium is right in the middle of a shopping center with several
Planetarium Galile is definitely place you are supposed to visit with your children while you visit Montpelliere.

We've previously been to the aquarium and we're pleased that it was as interesting as the last time we went. Still had plenty to see and now the octopus too which unfortunately didn't move whilst I was watching it. Love the penguins and the seahorses.

Having visited the aquarium 3 times in the past 3 years, it remains a great day out! There is so much packed into the aquarium I can't see why anybody would be unimpressed as there is something for everyone! The facilities are clean and modern, informative and interesting.

We are regular visitors to the South of France and we always make a point of coming to this aquarium. My 6 year old loves it and this year he got to take his 1 year old twin brother and sister round it. He was absolutely delighted, telling them all about the different sharks and

Very good aquarium with lots to see. Loads of different fish to see and the sharks are great. There is one section where you feel like you are on a boat which was really good even though a couple of people in our party felt seasick.
Bit expensive for the price compare with others in the region. Max one hour enough for the tour. The presentations are not bad. Located in the highly traffic area.

The aquarium is relatively small but it’s interesting. You might be disappointed if you are used to visiting vast, comprehensive marine animals collections, but if you are visiting Montpellier and want to spend a couple of hours this place is worth the €15.50 (adult priece) you

This is a large, well laid out and interesting aquarium with huge main tank filled with a variety of sharks, rays and other interesting large fish. It's at least on par with the London aquarium. One could comfortably spend a couple of hours here with the family. It's surrounded

We have visited a nmber of aquariums BUT I would definately say this si the best we have been to. It includes all the usual fish etc but also has a part which is like being on a fishing boat - you actually feel as if you are on the boat on a rough sea, they also have pengiuns

Kids love sea life, so we popped in for a quick visit. Finished in one hour, not sure that you can spend here longer than 2 hours without the kids getting bored. They have a great collection and the exhibitions are really good. Staff is helpful - definitely worth a short visit!

We visited this aquarium with 2 babies of 20 months. The aquarium is amazing, recent with great quality. It has a very nice selection of fishes including a lot of sharks. Most importantly, it is all organized around kids. If they are in a stroller, no worries as you have

Before I went I read the reviews and few of them discourage me, however my kids kept asking and we give it a go, I most said having been in London, Madrid, Barcelona acuarios that this one it is small, also cheaper but it has some interesting stuff that I have no seen before.

Travelled from city centre on the tram, which is clean and efficient. Aquarium was enjoyable - some good exhibits such as the penguin area. Visit took less than an hour but we didn't have small children with us.

We found this aquarium out after looking at places on a map. I've read a few of the reviews and quite a few people complained about there being empty tanks. They explained this and said that it was because of cleaning or caring reasons. At the entrance you have to open your
not too big, not too small, the visite is done in 2h. Many shops and restaurants around. easily accessible by tram.
Out side from Montpellier. Lot of fish from different country. Perhaps little expensive, but interesting exhibition.

We were amazed at this fantastic aquarium and highly recommend it! Stunning fish tanks and displays...lovely and easy to follow and great 'sections' that divide the various marine life zones around the world. Favourite bit was the ENORMOUS fish tank that you can sit and watch
Workers are nice, but once you go in, some of the fishtanks are empty and the penguin exhibit smells awful.

The aquarium is very nice, but you can be disappointed if you have visited before some large ones..... The price is tooo high for half an hour (that is how much you need to see everything calmly because the place is quite small )... They have some shows scheduled if you are

I enjoyed this trip as a 30 year old!!! I was in amazement at some of the features. Definitely recommend for 15 euros. It took me about 45 -60 mins to get around. I imagine if you had children you spend much more than this as they have slides and other features geared to

I have been there a few times after the opening, and their collections are impressive! Since then, some of the fish must have grown even bigger (especially the baracoudas in the big tank), so you should definitely check them out
This aquarium is a very nice place for a minimum of four hours visit. It is located in a shopping mall facility and it has easy access with the tram.

It's a nice way of spending your time. The price is a bit high, but the visit is very nice, the traject very well made, there are many species of fish and other creatures. I was pleased with the visit.

That's a very good place to visit especially during the rainy days, the sharks are amazing. Now after few of Aquariums like this one in France, they are all the same....don't expect to find The Aquarium :) !!! cheers

We took our three year old grand-daughter to the aquarium wondering if she would be interested. She was enchanted and we could not get her away. We spent about four hours walking around examining all the tanks. We looked at several more than once and enjoyed the interactive

Spent there several hours with French-speaking kids. Many different fishes, sharks and sea animals on show, some inter-active info available. Some of the written explanation is in English, otherwise you need to enjoy what you can see. Unsure that there are audio-guides. Many

I didn't expect to spend at least two hours in an aquarium. The large aquaria were fabulous. I don't know how long I spend with my nose glued against the glass staring at the sharks and other fish swimming overhead. I couldn't care less about all the semi scientific garbage at
We went here in the summer on a burning hot day day and our two kids loved it. Loads to see and a great option. I would highly recommend it,

if you have 2 hours spare in Montpellier, it's a great idea to take the tram 1 towards Odysseum, and visit the Aquarium. It feels like being in the water yourself surrounded by fish, amazing views and fun watching feedings. Guidance in French and English.

One of the best we have ever seen. This was a really well-conceived and interesting attraction.The themed experiences were especially impressive and for children the 'experience of the typhoon hit ship' was fascinating. GREAT. Must see.

The aquarium is nice for children and families, though some parts are just sad. The big fish tanks are interesting, and the fish seem to be ok (or as fine as a fish can get being confined in such small spaces I guess), the simulation of a boat in a storm is a delight for

This is a great experience, we spent just under 2 hours here. We arrived at about 11am and had to queue for about 15 minutes for tickets. There is a car park that gives you two hours free parking. The aquarium consists of a number of zones that feature each ocean or major sea.

Worth a visit, but cost Euro 31 for two. Good to see the penguins and the talks - for the money they should provide an English translation, perhaps via headphones as husband's French is not up to that level. NO toilet paper in an entire ladies' on the ground floor - had to use

The aquarium is not big but super nice! We loved it and our 2 years old was absolutely happy! They have a ship there with real storm ☺ and it's very realistic! I would definitely recommend this place.
Nice aquarium, good to see, not very big, it doesn't have a lot of variety of fish but it's worth visiting... Spend good time overthere
A great area of different displays, live creatures, perspectives of sea life. Much better than the average 'aquarium' - also providing welcome air conditioning on a hot August day!

Been to many aquariums such as London and seaworld in florida. Doesn't compare to those however still has some excellent fish tanks. Loved the marine fish including the puffa and cow fish. Some impressive sharks. There is a talk on the sharks however was in French. There are
I visited in July and it was wonderful to see different species of marine life. It is a nice and well-maintained place but it is rather small and not as vast as other major aquariums I've been to.

This is a great day out. Go early to avoid the queues. The penguins are really cool as are the different sharks. Lots to do and the info is given in English and French. Great for adults and kids. Allow about 3 hours for the full trip.
Good value for money. Plenty to see and do. The large shark tank was particularly impressive. Very educational place for the children also.
I took my friends to the Aquarium. Even though they did not speak French, there were many things to engage us at the visit. The Exhibition is well laid out and entire afternoon was enjoyable.

I went with my partner, sister, brother in law and 2 nephews, aged 12 and 10. We had a fantastic time! You can see the penguins being fed if you time your visit well. The smell if awful, but they are very cute, and the carers / animators are very interesting to listen to. There
An excellent aquarium. Great for the whole family. Lots of hands-on stuff. Excellent explanations and a realistic experience on a boat in a storm. A must-see for kids of all ages.

If you want to see marine animals and learn a lot about them visit this interesting aquarium. They com mostly from the Mediterranean Sea, hence the name "Mare nostrum", but penguins and tropical fish are not forgotten. You can also enjoy without anything to fear the thrills of a
This is a nice place to go with friends or with your family. Impressive aquarium where you can see real sharks! A place to go!

We visited the Aquarium on our last day in Montpellier. Beautifully kept and with some engaging details along the way (where the aquarium is set out like a boat, submarine etc). We particularly liked the penguins and watching the sharks. It was quite expensive (15.50€) for
There are bigger and better Aquaria in the world but this one in Montpellier deserves a visit. My wife and I thoroghly enjoyed the trip into the aquatic world.
This aquarium is just big enough for young children and quite fun The whole family loves this place.

I was expecting big things when I walked into the enchanting entrance, but as I walked further into the aquarium, I realised its just average compared to others I have visited. Also, I feel its not very visitor-friendly as not all the information boards are written in English.

I hadn't been to an aquarium for 40 years and wasn't at all sure I wanted to go to this but it was recommended by a friend who lived in Montpellier and we didn't regret following his advice. Lots of things to see and plenty of opportunities to learn about the ocean. Nicely

Not a bad attempt, went to the one at La Rochelle last year and found it to be a bit better, and La Rochelle is a small town. A bit expensive @ e15.50c each I thought, about half the price would be a true reflection of it's contents, The Ships bow video display was good though,

From the beginning I was impressed with the aquarium. It was huge, with many different activities, notably the life-like boat experience and the feeding of the penguins. Must-see for all animal lovers; the sharks were amazing, as well as the indoor waterfall. Loved it loved it

I love aquariums but this one was especially enjoyable. I went with my brother (12), my parents (50) and my Grandma (82) and everyone thoroughly enjoyed it. The range of fish is spectacular (especially the large shark tank), but it was the educational activities and parts where

I'm a big fan of aquaria and this one was right up there with the very best. Outstanding layout and content and very knowledgeable staff with a clear pride in where they were working. Highly recommended!

The planetarium itself is fantastic and has the capability of putting on a great show. However, this was really disappointing. I would recommend having a look at going to the 7+ one. The show was mostly about moles, worms and a spider very little to do with the stars or

It doesn't look like much from outside, but this place is great, very educational, it has some interesting activities like a wind demonstration and ecological movies. I'm 21 and I enjoyed it with my friends, I can imagine children also might enjoy it. I most enjoyed watching
Spent a few hours here on a wet and wild day weatherwise. Average aquarium, not up with the best ,but not the worst either.
A very nice aquarium with lots of sharks and the usual species. But, it also has a small but impressive collection of deep sea animals and fish from rare places around the world.

This was a memorable visit: enormous tank with enormous sharks, sword fish, penguins, tree slide which our toddler loved, brilliant simulation of a ship going through a storm - really made you feel like you were on board.

This is a really fun and relaxing experience in Montpellier. Next to a shopping mall, movie theaters; there is easy parking and even easier access by tram. Don't forget to validate your ticket after boarding, they have strict enforcement on those trams. We saw they removing two

I've been to this aquarium 3 times now, and everytime I love it! There are loads of different fish to see and it is a large set up which means you get your moneys worth (it isn't just over in 5 mins). The setting and scenery is very well done and makes it interesting and

Highly recommend and lovely to see all the fishes and the animals. So easy to find by parking near the tram line and within walking distance. Nice air conditioned building on a hot day was good for us. Our teenager kids loved all the zones to see and do.

We had to queue to get in as we visited in peak season, but the queues moved quickly and we were greeted by friendly, efficient and multi-lingual staff. This isn't the largest aquarium we have visited but it is well laid out and has a good range of exhibits. Particular

Although a good way to spend a wet afternoon, we only managed to make it last an hour (not the 2hr30 advertised!) and I was expecting a lot more given what you pay for it. Perhaps that's just because we weren't there with kids, but we certainly stopped to look at all the

The aquarium is built around a large shark tank. Guests start at the top and wind down though various exhibits. It is well-designed to engage young children, of which there were many on the day of our visit. My college-aged kids liked it very much and wished they had visited

This is a must for the family and can easily spend 2-3 hours in a calm and relaxing environment, the variety of the fish and getting up close is great, staff speak good English and were keen to introduce the various species and their knowledge, a great morning thank you
they have a cool shark aquarium to be seen, otherwise it is fine but not overwhelming like Marineland or Sea World
My 2 adult children and their parents all LOVED the Aquarium. Cool exhibits and exciting space. All the signage was in French, but we got the idea. Cool sea creatures. Go see it!

I have been there twice, and every time was a good experience. Staff is lovely and helpful. There is a lot to see (and a lot of space). I just think it is too expensive, even with reduced prices (students, etc.) I would recommend it though!

I liked this place. We went on a week day morning so there was no one there. It was really well organised, they had put a lot of effort into the displays and information, and most of all, the tanks were well maintained, meaning the fish didn't look too annoyed that they were

We spent about 3 hours wandering around, enjoying the animals and all the aquarium had to offer! The penguins and 'storm simulator' where highlights! (If you have children, hold on to them in the wind simulator!) Was surprised at how many things we see, do and play about with.

We had a fun hour and a half in the aquarium on a very busy day. There is a good variety of animals and plenty of different things to do, especially for younger children. Mine loved it and I would visit again!
This is a fun day out for kids and adults alike. We loved the penguins and the simulated boat on the high seas! Would definitely go back
Good range of displays and the shark tank is excellent. It is not too expensive and the rain forest cafe is a good place to grab something to eat.

A little pricey but well worth it! We spent a whole afternoon there looking at all the different sea life. It's right beside a shopping centre if anyone fancies some retail therapy after their visit. The gift shop in the aquarium is also very good!

Visited here recently, just out of the high summer season, and had a great afternoon. Entry feels a little expensive, but I think it's well worth it for the clean, modern and excellently presented aquarium. We took my 'spirited' two-year-old, and without doubt it has been the
Clean and detailed information. The kids loved the ship simulator, the big fish pool, and last the hurracaine simulator.
Very happy to go around. Typical aquarium experience - a little expensive when you look at the price, but when you go round, you see it's easily justified.

We took our pree-teens her for a day trip. We have been to aquariums all over the world and this is a good as any that we have been to. It is not cheap but it is worth the money. They have a virtual ship's bridge that is quite realistic and overall it is a very good experience.

We visited the aquarium in early July. We thoroughly enjoyed it particularly the penguins and the hurricane simulator and plenty to see. It was expensive as all aquariums are. It was very easy to get to by tram.
Our two year old daughter loved it- a great way to spend an afternoon, a great range of sea life we loved the penguins

Lovee the aquarium. Was a super visit well worth it. It has very varied basins with great varieties of fish. The texts are really good and the aquariums are amazing. There are some great shows too. Go and see it if you are in montpellier!

This is a very nice, if somewhat small, aquarium. Visitors get quite close to the animals in places - the penguins, especially. They though my daughter's camera was a fish, I guess- they followed her everywhere that they could. The tanks were very clean and clear, and the

The tanks and rooms of the exhibits are as good as the exhibits themselves. The offering is mainly fish with some penguins and reptiles. There are not any large exhibits such as whales. Make sure to spend extra time in the room that you captain a boat and experience all the

We have been to aquaria in many parts of the world and this is probably the most boring poorly laid out one that we have seen. The exhibits are poorly lit, many with small or inconveniently placed viewing portals. There are several “attractions” that were definitely created

Our second aquarium in two days (after the very good Seaquarium at La Grau du Roi), Mare Nostrum was different but equally enjoyable. The stand-out highlight is the ship in the storm, very cleverly done and not just for the kids. The arctic zone and its penguins were also an

The aquarium is well laid out and the fish are easy to observe. It has the added attraction of a ship on the high seas where visitors can experience what it is like to be at sea in the middle of a storm; it is very good for children.

This came highly recommended by a friend, and we were glad we listened to her. It's not a huge aquarium, but we definitely felt like we got our money's worth. Several times we thought we had gotten to the end, only to find there was another room... and another... It is a very

Not the word I would normally use for an Aquarium but this is special - theatrical in fact. First stop is on the bridge of a ship going through the "roaring forties" - you pitch and toss and water hurled at the windows and then the lights go out. Great and worth a visit

Easy to find, a big plus! Just off the motorway(Peage.) Well laid out with interesting displays and lots of fun for children of all ages, especially the "ship in a storm" and feeding of the various fish and other animals. Well thought out and much more "hands on" than many
Thought it was a bit expensive at 15 euros but well worth trhe money. Really well thought out but couldn't understand why cafe was closing at 2 o'clock!

The aquarium is made for kids in mind (5-12 years old is best I think). I went with my 5 years old son and his cousins (4 and 7) and they enjoy every bit of it. The displays are made a bit like a playhouse, you get to experience a storm in a fishing boat, go down a a submarine,

Really nice, not the best aquarium i've ever seen though. But for the price, you can expect a 1,5 hour tour. You will like the storm simulator, as well as the hurricane simulator. A lot of different species, fancy sceneries. Note: if you are an adult, you can skip the last 3D

The Aquarium Mare Nostrum is a fabulous aquarium. The price may seem a little high at around €15 for an adult ticket, but I can assure you it is well worth the price. All the facilities are very new and clean and user-friendly. Our favourite areas of the aquarium were the

text.wiki:
Montpellier (UK: , US: , French: [mɔ̃pəlje, -pɛl-] (listen); Occitan: Montpelhièr [mumpeˈʎɛ]) is a city near the south coast of France on the Mediterranean Sea. It is the capital of the Hérault department. It is located in the Occitanie region. In 2016, 607,896 people lived in the urban area and 281,613 in the city itself. Nearly one third of the population are students from three universities and from three higher education institutions that are outside the university framework in the city.


== Status ==
Montpellier is the third-largest French city on the Mediterranean coast after Marseille and Nice. It is the 7th-largest city of France, and is also the fastest-growing city in the country over the past 25 years.


== History ==


=== Medieval period ===
In the Early Middle Ages, the nearby episcopal town of Maguelone was the major settlement in the area, but raids by pirates encouraged settlement a little further inland. Montpellier, first mentioned in a document of 985, was founded under a local feudal dynasty, the Guilhem, who combined two hamlets and built a castle and walls around the united settlement. The name is from medieval Latin mons pislerius, referring to the woad used for dyeing locally. The two surviving towers of the city walls, the Tour des Pins and the Tour de la Babotte, were built later, around the year 1200. Montpellier came to prominence in the 12th century—as a trading centre, with trading links across the Mediterranean world, and a rich Jewish cultural life that flourished within traditions of tolerance of Muslims, Jews and Cathars—and later of its Protestants. William VIII of Montpellier gave freedom for all to teach medicine in Montpellier in 1180. The city's faculties of law and medicine were established in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad of Urach, legate of Pope Honorius III; the medicine faculty has, over the centuries, been one of the major centres for the teaching of medicine in Europe. This era marked the high point of Montpellier's prominence. The city became a possession of the Kings of Aragon in 1204 by the marriage of Peter II of Aragon with Marie of Montpellier, who was given the city and its dependencies as part of her dowry.
Montpellier gained a charter in 1204 when Peter and Marie confirmed the city's traditional freedoms and granted the city the right to choose twelve governing consuls annually. Under the Kings of Aragon, Montpellier became a very important city, a major economic centre and the primary centre for the spice trade in the Kingdom of France. It was the second or third most important city of France at that time, with some 40,000 inhabitants before the Black Death. Montpellier remained a possession of the crown of Aragon until it passed to James III of Majorca, who sold the city to the French king Philip VI in 1349, to raise funds for his ongoing struggle with Peter IV of Aragon. In the 14th century, Pope Urban VIII gave Montpellier a new monastery dedicated to Saint Peter, noteworthy for the very unusual porch of its chapel, supported by two high, somewhat rocket-like towers. With its importance steadily increasing, the city finally gained a bishop, who moved from Maguelone in 1536, and the huge monastery chapel became a cathedral. In 1432, Jacques Cœur established himself in the city and it became an important economic centre, until 1481 when Marseilles overshadowed it in this role.
From the middle of the 14th century until the French Revolution (1789), Montpellier was part of the province of Languedoc.


=== After the Reformation ===
At the time of the Reformation in the 16th century, many of the inhabitants of Montpellier became Protestants (or Huguenots as they were known in France) and the city became a stronghold of Protestant resistance to the Catholic French crown. In 1622, King Louis XIII besieged the city which surrendered after a two-month siege (Siege of Montpellier), afterwards building the Citadel of Montpellier to secure it. Louis XIV made Montpellier capital of Bas Languedoc, and the town started to embellish itself, by building the Promenade du Peyrou, the Esplanade and a large number of houses in the historic centre. After the French Revolution, the city became the capital of the much smaller Hérault.


=== Modern history ===

During the 19th century the city thrived on the wine culture that it was able to produce due to the abundance of sun throughout the year. The wine consumption in France allowed Montpellier's citizens to become very wealthy until in the 1890s a fungal disease had spread amongst the vineyards and the people were no longer able to grow the grapes needed for wine. After this the city had grown because it welcomed immigrants from Algeria and other parts of northern Africa after Algeria's independence from France. In the 21st century Montpellier is between France's number 7th and 8th largest city. The city had another influx in population more recently, largely due to the student population, who make up about one-third of Montpellier's population. The school of medicine kickstarted the city's thriving university culture, though many other universities have been well established there. The coastal city also has such developments as the Corum and the Antigone that have attracted an increasing number of students.

== Geography ==

The city is situated on hilly ground 10 km (6 mi) inland from the Mediterranean coast, on the River Lez. The name of the city, which was originally Monspessulanus, is said to have stood for mont pelé (the naked hill, because the vegetation was poor), or le mont de la colline (the mount of the hill)
Montpellier is located 170 km (106 mi) from Marseille, 242 km (150 mi) from Toulouse, and 748 km (465 mi) from Paris.
Montpellier's highest point is the Place du Peyrou, at an altitude of 57 m (187 ft). The city is built on two hills, Montpellier and Montpelliéret, thus some of its streets have great differences of altitude. Some of its streets are also very narrow and old, which gives it a more intimate feel.


=== Climate ===
Montpellier has a Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csa), with mild, damp winters, and hot, rather dry summers. The monthly mean ranges from 7.2 °C (45.0 °F) in January to 24.1 °C (75.4 °F) in July. Precipitation is around 630 millimetres (24.8 in), and is greatest in fall and winter, but not absent in summer, either. Extreme temperatures have ranged from −17.8 °C (−0.04 °F) recorded on 5 February 1963 and up to 43.5 °C (110.3 °F) on 28 June 2019.

== Population ==
The whole metropolitan area had a population of 510,400 in 2006. And in a study made by INSEE from 2007 to 2012 Montpellier saw the strongest population growth of France's main communes (+1.1%), ahead of Paris and Lyon. In 2011, the estimated population of the metropolitan area was 561,326.For most of its history, and even today, Montpellier is known for its significant Spanish population, heritage and influence. Montpellier also houses important Moroccan, Algerian, and Italian communities.


== Heraldry ==


== Sights ==

The main focus point of the city is the Place de la Comédie, with the Opéra Comédie built in 1888.
The Musée Fabre.
In the historic centre, a significant number of hôtels particuliers (i.e. mansions) can be found. The majority of the buildings of the historic centre of Montpellier (called the Écusson because its shape is roughly that of an escutcheon) have medieval roots and were modified between the 16th and the 18th centuries. Some buildings, along Rue Foch and the Place de la Comédie, were built in the 19th century.
The Rue du Bras de Fer (Iron Arm Street) is very typical of the medieval Montpellier.
The mikve, ritual Jewish bath, dates back to the 12th century and is one of very few in Europe.
The Jardin des plantes de Montpellier—oldest botanical garden in France, founded in 1593
The La Serre Amazonienne, a tropical rain forest greenhouse
The 14th-century Saint Pierre Cathedral
The Porte du Peyrou, a triumphal arch built at the end of the 17th century, and the Place Royal du Peyrou built in the 17th century, are the highest point of the Ecusson.
The Tour des Pins, the only remaining of 25 towers of the city medieval walls, built around 1200.
The Tour de la Babotte, a medieval tower which was modified in the 18th century to house an observatory.
The Saint Clément Aqueduct, built in the 18th century.
The Antigone District and other housing projects have been designed by the architect Ricardo Bofill from Catalonia, Spain
A number of châteaux, so-called follies, built by wealthy merchants surround the city
Nearly 80 private mansions were built in the city from the 17th to 19th century, and some of their interior courtyards are open


== Education ==


=== History ===
The University of Montpellier is one of the oldest in the world, founded in 1160, and having been granted a charter in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad von Urach and confirmed by Pope Nicholas IV in a papal bull of 1289. It was suppressed during the French Revolution but was
re-established in 1896.
It is not known exactly at what date the schools of literature were founded which developed into the Montpellier faculty of arts; it may be that they were a direct continuation of the Gallo-Roman schools. The school of law was founded by Placentinus, a doctor from Bologna University, who came to Montpellier in 1160, taught there during two different periods, and died there in 1192. The school of medicine was founded perhaps by a graduate of the Muslim Spain medical schools; it is certain that, as early as 1137, there were excellent physicians at Montpellier. The statutes given in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad, legate of Honorius III, which were completed in 1240 by Pierre de Conques, placed this school under the direction of the Bishop of Maguelonne. Pope Nicholas IV issued a Bull in 1289, combining all the schools into a university, which was placed under the direction of the bishop, but which in fact enjoyed a large measure of autonomy.
Theology was at first taught in the convents, in which St. Anthony of Padua, Raymond Lullus, and the Dominican Bernard de la Treille lectured. Two letters of King John prove that a faculty of theology existed at Montpellier independently of the convents, in January 1350. By a Bull of 17 December 1421, Martin V granted canonical institution to this faculty and united it closely with the faculty of law. In the 16th century the faculty of theology disappeared for a time, when Calvinism, in the reign of Henry II of France, held complete possession of the city. It resumed its functions after Louis XIII had reestablished the royal power at Montpellier in 1622; but the rivalries of Dominicans and Jesuits interfered seriously with the prosperity of the faculty, which disappeared at the Revolution. The faculty numbered among its illustrious pupils of law Petrarch, who spent four years at Montpellier, and among its lecturers Guillaume de Nogaret, chancellor to Philip the Fair, Guillaume de Grimoard, afterwards pope under the name of Urban V, and Pedro de Luna, antipope as Benedict XIII. But after the 15th century this faculty fell into decay, as did also the faculty of arts, although for a time, under Henry IV of France, the latter faculty had among its lecturers Casaubon.
The Montpellier school of medicine owed its success to the ruling of the Guilhems, lords of the town, by which any licensed physician might lecture there; there was no fixed limit to the number of teachers, lectures were multiplied, and there was a great wealth of teaching. Rabelais took his medical degrees at Montpellier. It was in this school that the biological theory of vitalism, elaborated by Barthez (1734–1806), had its origin. The French Revolution did not interrupt the existence of the faculty of medicine.
The faculties of science and of letters were re-established in 1810; that of law in 1880. It was on the occasion of the sixth centenary of the university, celebrated in 1889, that the Government of France announced its intention—which has since been realized—of reorganizing the provincial universities in France.

== Transport ==

Montpellier is served by railway, including TGV highspeed trains. Montpellier's main railway station is Saint-Roch. There are plans to construct a high-speed railway linking Nîmes and Montpellier with the LGV Méditerranée.

The Montpellier – Méditerranée Airport is located in the area of Fréjorgues, in the town of Mauguio, southeast of Montpellier.
The Transports de l'agglomération de Montpellier (TaM) manages the city's public transportation, including its 56-kilometre (35 mi) tramway network consisting of four lines and several parking facilities. Line 1 runs from Mosson in the west to Odysseum in the east. Line 2 runs from Jacou in the northeast to St. Jean-de-Vedas in the southwest. Line 3 and Line 4 opened in April 2012. Line 3, which is 22.4-kilometre (13.9 mi) long, links Juvignac and Perols with a branch to Lattes and serves 32 stations. Line 4 circles the centre and serves as a connector line between the various arms of tram system. They intersect at Gare St. Roch station, Rives du Lez and Corum.
The TaM also manages the large bike sharing scheme Vélomagg', started in June 2007, comprising 1200 bicycles and 50 stations.


== Sport ==

Montpellier was the finish of Stage 11 and the departure of Stage 12 in the 2007 Tour de France.  It was also the finish of Stage 11 and the departure of Stage 12 in the 2016 edition. The city is home to a variety of professional sports teams:

Montpellier Hérault Rugby, of the Top 14 who play rugby union formerly at the Stade Sabathé and now at the Altrad Stadium. In the 2010/2011 season, the team made it to the Top 14 Final against the Stade Toulousain.
Montpellier HSC of Ligue 1 who play association football at the Stade de la Mosson. MHSC became French Champions on 20 May 2012.
Montpellier Red Devils who play rugby league in Elite 1 division at the Stade Sabathé
Montpellier Agglomération Handball are a team handball club playing in the French National League.
Montpellier Vipers of France's Division 1 ice hockey Federation, play at the Patinoire de l'Agglomération de Montpellier at Odysseum
Montpellier Water Polo play in the National League and European Cup competitions.
Barracudas de Montpellier is a baseball club, and competes in Division Élite, a French top level baseball league.Montpellier was one of the hosts of the FIBA EuroBasket 2015.
The city is home to the Open Sud de France tennis tournament since 2010, and will host the XXXI World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championship.
The main athletics stadium is the Philippidès Stadium, which is owned by the University of Montpellier.


== Culture ==
The city is a centre for cultural events as there are many students. Montpellier has two large concert venues: Le Zenith Sud (7.000 seats) and L'Arena (14.000 seats). Le Corum cultural and conference centre contains three auditoriums.

The Festival de Radio France et Montpellier is a summer festival of opera and other music held in Montpellier. The festival concentrates on classical music and jazz with about 150 events, including opera, concerts, films, and talks. Most of these events are free and are held in the historic courtyards of the city or in the modern concert halls of Le Corum near historical city center.
The annual Cinemed, the International Mediterranean Film Festival Montpellier, held in the fall, is the second largest French film festival after the Cannes Film Festival. Held since 1979, it offers screenings of over 200 long and short films, documentaries, animated films, trailers, and a special program of student films. Other events include panel discussions, exhibitions, and gatherings. Venues include Le Corum and cinema halls.

== Other locations named after Montpellier ==
"Montpellier" is used as the name of other towns and streets in as many as four continents. Many places in England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland carry the name Montpellier. Often they are in resort locations claiming some of the healthy attributes for which the French city was renowned in earlier centuries. The variant spelling "Montpelier" is common, and is of quite early provenance. Brewer uses that spelling. The first example was the early 19th-century suburb of Montpelier in Brighton.The capital of the American state of Vermont was named Montpelier because of the high regard in which the Americans held the French who had aided their Revolutionary War against the British. Several other American cities are also named Montpelier.
Places named Montpellier/Montpelier are also found in Australia, Canada, South Africa, and the Caribbean.
