On our way it is worthwhile to stop here and visit this beautiful theatre. Although an entry fee it is managable and offes you a great site. At the exit do not forget to buy the € 0.- note for € 2.- ;)

Given it is something approaching 2000 years old and has had several different uses over its life, the amphitheatre at Arles is both is great condition and very impressive. Having visited the Coliseum, the Alres Arena is actually more complete and although much smaller (not
The fact that it still exists is really the main draw for this ancient amphitheater. We toured it in a half and hour and were glad to have seen it but were not blown away.
Did not have the opportunity to enter this arena, much less watch one of bull fights (display?) for the fair, but from the outside, day and night, this location was truly impressive.

Arena built by the romand started around 1 AD how good is that. Still used today for festivals and bull fights
Great family activity. And the view from the top level was breath taking. Moderately priced and worth the cost.

Montpellier Toruist Office had little information. Had to establish an account before purchasing seats. Three credit cards refused. When I was called, the agent answered but said they were about to close and I would have to call back in the morning, the day of the event.
It was my first time here I love the city and the arena was super good, good atmosphere I got chance yesterday to see the Féria d’Arles. Good experience.

Well preserved structure, built by the Romans in 90 AD, impressive from the outside. The two tiered interior reportedly held up to 20,000 people. Did not enter, as the interior was obscured by metal railings and bleachers set up for the start of the bull fighting season.

This is Arles main attraction and it is still in use today for bloodless bullfights. It is dead center in the Old Town, so you really can't miss it. While nowhere near as big as the Roman Colliseum, it is a fine example of an amphitheater in the provinces

Medieval cobbled streets and alleyways surrounds this impressive colosseum. The views of Arles and the Rhone river from the top are amazing. There is so much history here, a reminder of the Roman Empire's occupation of France and their incredible medieval architecture. In the
Wonderful history and well preserved amphitheater. Great use of a historic structure. Loved the area around the area too. Well worth it. Get a museum pass. Such a great deal.

The Roman arena is now used to stage bullfights! The cost was a bit steep for the visit €9.50 although this also included the theatre which was in a bad state of preservation. I believe the theatre in Orange to the north is better preserved.

Among Roman amphitheater’s, this is 20th in size. The most compelling thing is how this has been painstakingly restored over the centuries and is now used. The liberty pass gets you into several monuments and museums for 11 euros. This is definitely worth a look. Sitting in
Very impressive building with amazing views of Arles and the river from the tower. Very good price of 4 monuments for €12. Definitely go and see this.
Beautiful roman arena constructed with a shiny white stone. To me this arena is a nice as the Colosseo in Rome and much nicer than the one in Verona (Italy).
Rather well preserved Roman amphitheatre, providing pehaps the best view of the town from the top of the two medieval towers inserted at opposite ends of the arena.

This colosseum is a must see! We were on a tour with Viking River Cruise so I'm not sure if there's a fee or if there's a tour available but it's worth visiting nonetheless. This massive colosseum is in the middle of this quaint French town of Arles just off of the Rhone River.

We visited this to view Bull Fighting Carmargue Style - the bulls do NOT get killed or injured. This was quite an experience and can be recommended if only to see the fitness and energy of the boys/men who tackle speedy and sharp horned bulls. It gives you a chance to sit back
I felt back in time, explanations can be found in place since roman till middle ages , a roman ruins that must be seen
A must see if visiting Arles. A historic site from the times of the Romans. The surrounding area with Roman remains is also interesting.
It is much more fascinating seeing the amphitheatre from outside than from inside. The tribune is almost all covered by the scaffholdings for seatings.

The amphitheater is an imposing structure, and seeing it from the street was impressive. I would have been fine with only looking at it from the outside. A few minutes inside was more than enough for me.

This ancient Roman amphitheater was built in 90 AD. It is still used today for bullfighting, plays, and concerts. It was pretty amazing to be seated on stone that early Romans sat on to cheer on whatever was going on below. This is a must see in Arles.

This Amphiteatre dominates this part of Arles. The interpretive displays under the stands are interesting, but you can't go on the arena floor and access to the stands is limited as well. I though the charge was a bit high for what you got. Fortunately we has visited the

Nice and impressive building-ish with a nice location. I'm not sure if you can normally enter, but the two times I passed by, it was not possible. It's still a nice view and if you happen to be in Arles, you should definitely check it out
We spent a couple of hours viewing the amphitheatre as there is so much to see and the views of the city from the top are spectacular. Not to be missed.

Built about 90 A.D. by the Romans, this amphitheatre held an impressive 20,000+ spectators. It's in good shape and is unusual in that two towers were added on to the top of the structure during the Middle Ages, making it look to me like a gigantic crown set upon the ground.

A visit to the amphitheater in Arles is far more enjoyable than the Colosseum in Rome. It's far more intact (still in use), far less crowded, and much more of the structure is open to visitors. There are even toilets!!

Like lots of things in Arles, you can visit the Amphithéâtre in a totally unstructured way and explore for yourself. Great views of the town from the top. A grey cat was wandering around the sand of the arena. I guess since the Roman Empire collapsed, they don’t have the budget

This place is awesome! Hard to believe how complete it is. Excellent side exhibits, too, gladiator costumes, bullfighter costumes, history and photographic displays. It is very “do at your own pace”, which is so agreeable...no large tour groups tramping through. Although we
Worth to have a stroll in the old town to see the arena. Looks nice even in the evening. Nîmes arena is bigger but Arles is also worth seeing.

Having been to see the arena in Nimes the previous day, this was still stunning but a little anticlimactic. It's slightly smaller, and currently appears to be in not such a good state of repair, although it was clear from the many clean and perfect stones that restoration work

This is a very well preserved arena that still functions for bull fights. Go ahead and see the nearby amphitheater that is packaged with the admission ticket. Amazing what those Romans accomplished more than 2,000 years ago.
We stayed within steps of the arena and enjoyed seeing it each time we returned to our home base. The entire arena is accessible to visitors and the history is fascinating.
step back in time to when matadors fought bulls well worth a visit and the shops in the area are cool too
It is a great Romans place but it is smaller than the similar one in Nimes. Inside is simple and still can be used.

I've seen several amphitheatres before in various countries and this is up there with the best. It's still being used for concerts and plays but unfortunately non were scheduled for when we were there but our local guide goes regularly. A little taste of the Romans in Provence!
So many people have gone into detail on this... Suffice it to say that it is a don't - miss sight, and since it is one of the five major things in town, and the biggest, you will head there anyway.
I am always amazed by the scale of Roman architecture and engineering. The fact that they pulled it off on this scale without the benefit of modern machinery makes it alone worth the visit!

Go to the top of the one tower that faces the Rhône and you will get spectacular views of the city and the Rhône.

Awesome to see that the Amphitheatre (les Arenas) is being restored and still in use today. Amazing feeling as we walked right around the whole thing. Got in early before there were too many visitors.

It was better preserved than the one in Rome . An absolutely Y amazing structure. We could only look inside as it is closed from time to time

The high spot of any visit to Arles! However, we paid €9 each to get in only to find the entire place covered with metal seating and scaffolding prior to an impending bull-fight. Bitterly disappointed! A complaint met with a Gallic shrug!

An excellent stop as you explore the old town area of Arles, from the time the Roman Empire held sway over most of the Mediterranean. Also don't miss the Theatre Antique, so many historic sites in this area.
If you love history and architecture, then you will be interested. This is not a place to walk, but some parts look fascinating. Probably, when events take place here, it becomes more interesting.

Excellently preserved Roman amphitheater worth the visit. Easy to image the gladiators fighting here.
It is very good to see a structure that still stands after 2000 years. However, the more impressive is the layout of this Amphitheatre, unchanged - most of the stadium today has the same layout.
Even that the place is under reconstruction, it looms very original and im a very good condition. Excelent place to visit
Amphitheatre worth the visit , but could do with a little more information regarding its history and the restoration. However it is used a a venue for numerous activitys so well done
its a nice place you should visit also you can enjoy a break around the area . its a very big and old theatre
From Roman times, still active. Performances of music or bull fightings. Beautifully kept. Next to it is another Roman forum.
I'm not sure why but given the hype from the locals about it being virtually intact I was expecting a bit more. Very little background info in English and not that much to it.
The amphitheater has been cleaned and restored. It sits right in town surrounded by cafes and ancient buildings still used today. The town was advertising bullfights there in October.
This amphitheatre is located in a high part of town and was built in Roman times. it looks impressive from the outside. We were surprised to learn that Bullfights still take place here.

This Roman arena must have been impressive in its day. Still mostly intact and accessible. There is Camargue Bull fighting here throughout the year and it can hold a fair few people. The view from the tower above the entrance is good. You get a fine view of the surrounding area

well worth seeing though it is a bullring inside and has modern simple seating however that probably gives more of an idea of what it actually looked like when in use

Visited using the Arles pass that covers a few historical sites. We also had the electronic guide that we full of interesting information. All in all we were given a fresh, non Hollywood version, of Roman history. It is considered the best preserved arena and is still in use

The Colosseum seated 20,000 and is in fine display. It is still in use for various events.It is a must do if you are in Arles.
We joined the English guided tour. The guide was informative and patient. Remember to get the package ticket which covers the major sites.

The whole town seems to show up in costume for this - do make sure to have a can of water mist as it gets VERY hot, no shade. A parasol even better. Free display each month - well worth doing once. The horses are amazing, children perform too, lovely tradition.

Traditional contest, where the young men try to snatch ribbons off the bulls horns-great fun-and no blood!
This is a well maintained Amphitheater and worth the stop, especially if you are staying locally... surrounded by the old town of Arles and numerous places to eat, stop and take a look at history.
The amphitheatre was beautiful and unexpected. It's a beautiful city and very walkable. Arles was definitely a find.

Enjoyed it with the pass .. lucky to accidentally hit the gladiator show .. otherwise might have been a snoozer.

This amphitheatre is very well preserved and well worth a visit even if only from the outside. Lots of souvenir shops around it.
As most reviews already state, just visit the amphitheatre from the outside. Under renovation which shows you the difference between the old and the renovated part, nice to see.

What awesome history. Must see. Kids are free. Only 9 euros. Feels so awesome inside. Great views of Arles. Parking is insane though.

If this is on when you are in town, do not miss it! 11 euro and a great adventure! The excitement I suppose you feel at bullfighting, but no one is hurt. The razateurs try to cut a ribbon from between the bull's horns. It is very exciting! Cool arena too!

Based on the Colosseum the structure is impressive and still in use. We had not realised there would be a show but many afternoons seem to feature some activity. The 13euro each for a ticket was well worth it both to explore the structure and to see the spectacle of young men

Just impressive. A place to visit. Nothing to spend hours unless you viait a show there. But a must see.
This amphitheatre is much bigger than I thought it would be ,and still in use for modern day shows worth a visit and easy to find.

The Roman Amphitheater is very well preserved and is even used for the bull. From the tower there is a very good view of the whole city.

Although there are lots of information notices around the arena, we would recommend that you take the free guided tour which is really interesting.

When travelling one is always astounded at what has survived the centuries and how sites such as this brings alive events of the past.
very beautiful and very interesting... historical monument. definitely worth a visit or at least a walk

Amphitheatre in Arles is just amazing. Just like others magnificent buildings that Romans built. Arles as a city it's like history (Ancient Rome) jewel of France. It's not that big as others, but it's still worth of visit. We were there in July and as I we got in, there were
That the Romans were building something like this while we were living in mud huts speaks volumes. It is so dramatic and great it is STILL used as a venue....

I'm amazed that such structures still remain standing after all these years. This is another must see in Arles

This well preserved Roman arena is well worth a visit. We were even fortunate to see two gladiators performing a pretty good fight for a party of school children as a docent explained to them the history and how the fight was being conducted. No blood on the sand fortunately!

The arena is restored well but ruined with all the sits for the bull corrida or manifestation like that. Nothing special

Amazing amphitheater , so old , great view from top of it. Reminded us of colosseum , it was a shame to see all the modern scaffolding and seating in there as took away from the ruins . They still use it today though which is quite incredible
It is pretty much intact and very impressive to see the size and imagine the busy life here more the 2 thousand years ago.
Fantastic arena from Roman times. Very large and well preserved. Really worthwhile seeing this structure to marvel at its size and what it used to be like.

the amphitheatre is a good example but there are lots of scaffolding , however its easy to get the atmosphere of what it must have been like. no admission discount for senior citizens

The Arenes amphitheatre is a magnificanr restoration the gives the fell of Roman strength and power in the peak of their domination of France. The sheer engineering ability in an age before modern plant is a sight to behold

We visited the arena on our first day and upon walking up it was breathtaking when you think about how long ago it was built.
The Amphitheatre in Arles, France is an incredible piece of lasting history. Explore and understand the reach of the ancient Romans and their architecture. It's worth the visit.
Great visit stop I'm the museum pass. Hard to believe this ancient place is still used for bullfights and other events.
I found this Colosseum totally different and very impressive that many other ones I have seen before.
Stunning Roman relic still in use for events well worth a visit. It is amazing to imagine that it is still in use after almost two thousand years.

When you first come upon this site your first thought is of Rome's Colosseum because of it design. Of course it is much smaller. Interesting aspect is that it is still used today for bull contests and other events. Hard to miss from anywhere in town an should be a must see.

The arena is very impressive - well maintained for its age. The history is fascinating, especially the fact that there were houses inside during the Middle Ages. Impressive that it is still being used today.

The amphitheatre is a great Roman remain, a must visit. Even though the upper levels of the original Roman building have gone what you can go round is an authentic Roman arena, one that is still used.

This is a must see. The Roman amphitheater is in pristine shape and quite beautiful juxtaposed to the French shops and cafes.

My hotel faced this large coliseum from one BC. It was interesting to see for awhile then it just became a nuisance to walk around.

After passing the ticket kiosk, find the English display under the second arch describing the arena's history and renovation. The arena is a fine example of Roman engineering. The entrance fee is covered by the Liberty Pass. Open year round

Worth a visit to view the outside but once inside what a disappointment it was to me. Full of metal seating stands to support bull fight viewing. The whole grandure of the theatre and Roman skill was lost in a mess of steel.

Just like the colosseum but on a smaller scale, worth going into a you can get close to all the action, would have loved to see the bullfighting

This alone with the Coliseum is worh the trip to Arles. Beautiful Roman structure with plenty of steps to climb!

Built by the Romans, and modeled after it's counterpart in Rome, this colliseum is a marvel. Just the fact that it still stands is a tribute to the engineering ability of the Romans. It is still in use for concerts and annual ceremonies. Stadiums today should last as long!
this is a restored amphitheater - with lots of 'downed' pedestals etc. they do have concerts here in the summer

The arena attracts, but remains unreachable. At several other sites, one can go down to the arena of the amphitheatre. In Arles, I did not find it possible (oh yeah, I may have been ungainly, myself. Or it may really be restricted). Yet, having been to Rome's Coliseo and several

In the heart of the town, the area still inspires a feeling of awe. It has survived the millennia, despite being used as a quarry and a fortified town, now being preserved as a wonderful arena. I wish I could witness the Féria to be held here over Easter as I'm sure it will be
Amazing! Well worth a visit and a wander. Such a sense of history around you. The walk up the tower is well worth the walk. Affords great views
Lovely day out on holidays with the children and grandchildren. Perfect day which suited all of us. Really good atmosphere in the arena and you could easily imagine what it was like back in the day..

Interesting amphitheatre. Worth seeing even if you have seen the Colosseum in Rome (which we saw a year ago). Suffers a bit by comparison to Nimes amphiteatre, which is well-preserved and has excellent audioguide. This one in Arles actually seems bigger. Climb to top for

Very interesting to see a 2000 year old building still in use for public spectacles today. The programme of restoration works is impressive and the info boards have a s mattering of English as Wells's French. Just around the corner from the theatre.

I prefer this as an example of a roman amphitheatre to visit than the Colosseum in Rome. There's nobody hassling you, it's easy to walk around, not full of cats and just as spectacular in it's architecture.

We stayed in Arles on our way to the south coast on a motorcycle tour. Visited here in the evening, about an hour before closing so was good and quiet. Took about 45 minutes to walk around and look at everything and was well worth the 18 Euros for the two of us (without the
This amazing old place in the centre of Arles is still in use today. Far more impressive than I thought it would

It's a very interesting visit nonetheless, specially if you've never seen a roman arena before. But the structures mounted to allow the place to be used for shows and other events take away all the ambiance, as you can see in the pictures. It's worth a visit anyway, but it could
I took a tour in French although my french is less than good and enjoyed it very much. I would suggest to read some history before you visit.
This is an amazing preserved Roman amphitheater and was quite the surprise for us to find in the South of France. We thoroughly enjoyed exploring this piece of history.

You will not miss the best preserved Roman amphitheater in Europe. Of course you will compare the Coliseum, but ... arena is "whole", offers a sharper image and on a combat theater of antiquity. Hats off for the way in which it was preserved!
Amazing amphitheater that has been redone and is used for events currently.climb to the top for some great views of the city.

Simply put this is one of the finest ancient ampitheatre's in the world. In the heart of the lovely Provence town of Arles, it really is a must see!. Take care with the steps though if you are less mobile there are many if you want to see the best views.
We saw a show at Christmas and it was fabulous. The security was very good and it was a brilliant experience. I highly recommend going at Christmas.
At the centre of Arles a great piece of city history and well preserved. A very nice area to visit and go around

While not as big as the amphitheater in Rome, more of this structure has been better preserved/reconstructed. These structures look better when they have not been completely destroyed by subsequent people using them for rock quarries. You get a really good sense of the size of

Advertised as one of the best preserved arenas from the ancient Roman world, in fact, this arena is well preserved, mainly due to the fact it has been in use for almost 2000 years. Smaller than the Roman coliseum, but basically the same concept, it is a great example of Roman
Really very well preserved and almost as impressive as Rome itself. Entry fee but very little info provided for it better to look it up on the unesco site
this is a well-preserved, maintained amphotheatre. a truly amazing building which you can examine in detail. Vast areas have been well reconstructed. You must visit
Loved outside (the place closed minutes before we arrived there). Definitely a place to visit next time (with doors open).

This is probably the best preserved Roman coliseum I have seen. Still in very good condition and much has been restored. Gives a great idea of what it was like to watch the fights, races, etc in the Roman era. The tour guide provided very good description and in particular the
Stunning by night just to wander around and so much quieter than the daytime. Lots of restaurants to sit at and admire the view.
While not as big as the Colosseum in Rome, it is completely there and still used, these days for bull fights. The english audio tour is worth the small cost.

The amphitheater is right in the middle of the old town. We were lucky to get a parking space across the street. The amphitheater is still in use and it's fun to see the seat numbers on the stone seats. You can get around pretty quickly. I liked this mini coliseum. You

This is a definitely must see. The amphitheater is smaller than the coliseum in Rome, but it's just as impressive. Apparently, it is still being used. A friend mentioned that she was able to see a concert in it. This would have been a wonderful experience and I wish we would

The full-size arena gives one a strong impression of how the original facility must have looked. The various seating areas are easily accessible. Most interesting are the vaults and galleries behind the seating areas. The significant amount of reconstruction detracts somewhat
Unfortunately it was closed when we visited, but it was very worth while the overnight stay to see it regardless.

La Corrida is something very cruel as anyway the bull pay this fight with his death. But it is very interesting to observe the rules, the different practice how the bull is slowly fighted, made him weak and finally killed.

Beautiful and a must-do visit. You really live history there. Children don't pay, adults 8 euros. Open from 9 to 6 in October. T'he ticket includes visita to t'he antique theatre. Bonita y obligatoria visita donde uno vive la historia. Niñs no pagan, adultos 8 euros. Abierto de
In the middle of the historic center. Good info about the history of the arena which is still in use.

Having been to Rome, I was unsure about this one. However in many ways, I liked it better. The scale is such that it was comprehensible in its scale, function and construction. Plus, they're still using it for bull fights, which significantly helps its energy. Make sure you
Impressive amphitheater. Definitely worth a visit when in Arles. It's very close to the Colosseum, also worth a trip.

We loved walking round the arena. Who would have thought this 'very' complete arena still existed in this beautiful french town! It was like a slightly smaller version of Rome but without the mass of tourists! Great to hear it is still in use as well!
This Ampitheatre is one of the top 20 of the ancient roman ampitheatres. It once held close to 20,000 people. There are great views of the city and the Rhone from the top levels.
Loved visiting the arena. We did not use the audio tour we just strolled through the arena. Beautiful view of Arles from the top of the arena.

Quite an amazing to have a Roman amphitheatre in the centre of a bustling city that is now in use as the local bull ring! It is huge and in very good condition considering the age, but I imagine its continued use as a bull ring has something to do with that. Well worth a visit.

It was nice to go inside and see it. We had a local guide with us and learned that it was actually saved because local people started moving in and building "homes' in the amphitheater many, many years ago. Many years passed, and the powers that be realized what a jewel they
This amphitheatre is extraordinarily well preserved and in excellent condition. There are numerous multilingual signboards around the property that explan things well. Worth a visit.
We visited this attraction after buying a multi pass, which was well worth it and an easy to do option. This was an interesting place to visit.
This is a well preserved roman amphitheatre in the centre of Arles. It is worth a wander about to see the columns around the structure as well as the amphitheatre itself.

Deciding between Average and Above Average was difficult. The amphitheater has been amazingly well preserved. You can walk around the exterior and understand the size of the structure. Built in the 1st century B.C. to accommodate about 10,000 spectators the amphitheater
Having been to the Colosseum in Rome, I wasn't sure it would be worth it. It definitely is. Very impressive and better preserved than Rome.
if you like bull fights and you are in Arles in July or August , even Septembre, you can watch this unique spectacle. not for every one thought

Interesting and well presented. You need to be reasonably agile however as steps are high and there are lots of them. Within a few minutes of Hotel du cloitre and hotel Amphiteatre. You can get a joint ticket for up to 4 antiquities and this one is a stonesthrow from the Ancient
This is a must-see historic arena in Arles. It is worth a trip to this area just to wander the massive monument to Roman engineering.
Having just been to the one in Nimes. We all agreed we liked the arena at Arles better, more interesting stonework, lovely views from the top.

The shell of the outer walls remain standing in the large amphitheatre in Arles. Quite impressive. For a small entrance fee you can go inside which is recommended. There is a good view from the top of the stands over the town to the Rhone river. In the theatre there is lots of
If you are visiting Arles and Nimes,You must make a point of experiencing the incredible Roman architecture of the area. The arenas, temples and amphitheaters are inspiring.

Les Arenes (Roman Amphitheatre) in the southern French town of Arles is an excellent and smaller version of what you might see in Rome - only this one is in Provence. Built in 90 A.D., it could hold up to 20,000 spectators for the many gladiator games and chariot races popular

What an exceptional place to visit and such a surprise, right in the middle of town. Even though we knew of the existence and some of the history of this site, to see it first hand is so different. It is in great condition and the audio tour is really informative without being

This is really a must see if your in Arles.The amphtheatre is still in use today.It is very well maintained and still holds events.When we were there it held a bullfight(which it does twice a year.) The festival that weekend was a rice festival with many of the local restaurants
Really enjoyed this smaller version of Rome's Colosseum. Fewer crowds, accessible views. The from the tower is breathtaking (if you can make the steps).

My wife and I visited the Roman Amphitheatre on a hot Provencal day. 39 degrees. the arena is massive but acts like a mirror for the sun, making moving around inside even more uncumfortable. The parts of the amphitheatre are linked with cool (mercifully) unlit tunnels, so it was

I visited with a combined ticket for only €9, it's available online or at the tourism office of Arles. It's pretty well preserved. But at the same time you can see some protection they put for the architecture also some extra seats (because they still use it for some event

The Arena is an impressive structure with very clever and complementary modern renovations. It is imposing as you near it, imposing as you as you enter and look up and just intriguing as you sit in one of the seats to contemplate the spectacles that have taken place there over

Tourists, including men in tank tops, so forth, took our astonished eyes away some of the stunning features of this Roman built Goliath. When we lasted visited Arles in 1961, Arles had still to be discovered, so fortunately there were no security guards to keep us from crawling
Well worth the visit. Easily accessible from Central Arles. Amazing to see this ancient ruin. You can visit both Arenas. The original one has a small entry fee to roam around.
Major roman amphitheater, historical monument . Walk around the outside for free, or pay to go inside.
We did not take the time to go inside although maybe we should've. It's marvelous from the outside. By here are many signs in English that explain the history as well as the current restoration.
Enjoy a moonlight walk through time to avoid the daytime crowds. Follow this up with the Van Gogh Walk as the 1st "easel" is located here

If you have seen one you have seen them all and this has nothing special t offer. Unfortunately when we were there the seats from the bull fights were still installed so takes away the enjoyment. Not sure When /if they are taken down

This amazing structure built right in the middle of town and very well preserved is huge. The rest of the town has been built around it and it still dwarfs everything else. It is in a rather scruffy area of town that I would not like to visit at night but even so it is well

The grand amphitheatre is Arles' historical pride and attraction, a very well-maintained structure that serves as a venue for concerts, operas and other cultural events even in this day and age. Truly stunning.

...this superbly preserved Roman amphitheatre in the middle of Arles. Wonderfully preserved. You may find, as I did, the metal staircases and supports obtrusive, but overall it's not to be struck by this 2000 year old building. Don't miss it!

Plan your trip to Arles to take in the Friday night bull racing. It has a great atmosphere set in the old Colosseum and was great fun. Hard to describe ( not bullfighting - the bull does not get hurt) but very enjoyable.
Lovely place to visit. Very relaxing and beautiful views, although not very much information for tourists. Make sure to pick up a Liberte pass from the tourist office. Will save you a lot of money!
Saw the bull fighting match here. They don't harm the bulls like they do in Spain. It was a hot day but very much enjoyed it!

We visited this attraction as part of a multi ticket offer. The arena is now used for shows involving bulls (but not fights). It has wonderful views from the top of the tower and guided tours are available. The structure is in good condition and has plenty of interesting

We hadn't planned on seeing the Courses Camarguaises while visiting Arles, but were so glad we had the opportunity to do so. It was a history lesson about the horses and bulls grown in this area and the traditions surrounding them. The bull fight was very interesting. We had
we could really witness the Roman influence in this city. A trip not to miss in family or couple but in cool weather

Aside from the obvious historical interest of this amazingly well-preserved Roman coliseum, it's definitely worth checking out for the bloodless bull games played here. Lots of excitement in the air as the young men try to pull ribbons off the horns of occasionally angry and

This was a great experience for the entire family. We started early in the day with a tour of the arena. They offer English speaking guides but we decided to go it alone. We soaked in a lot of history and got some great photos of the surrounding town and countryside. Later

Yes but it's virtually complete a right bang in the centre of town. They do hold gladiator and bull fighting exhibitions but I found that these are aimed at tourists, predominantly French at that. That said its well worth a visit as the building is very complete and being

A classic Roman arena, mostly intact, remarkable architecture. Not as large or complete as the one in nearly Nimes (which should not be missed). Highlight was the wonderful bull show on Wednesday nights. They run after the bull, trying to grab a marker from between his horns.

Returned especially for the bi-weekly bull fight and horse show. Well advertised around the arena and town. Arrived to be told in typical 'couldn't care less attitude' it was cancelled. It felt like it was regularly cancelled...

The Arles Amphitheatre is a stunning reminder of the power of ancient Rome. While it is much smaller than its slightly older counterpart in Rome, the Colosseum, it is somewhat better preserved (or rather reconstructed) and is still in use today. We visited the Arena (as it's
Sadly I Could not understand a word as everything was in French. At the start of the gladiator talk. Thus it was aimed a French tourists.
A real highlight of our visit to the fascinating town of Arles! Would recommend to anyone, it must be seen if you are there!
We visited the arena as part of out boat trip and it's about a 10 minute walk from the jetty. Fantastic area but very hot! Still used today
great place - very few people there whilst we were there, which enabled us to absorb the atmosphere and be taken back 2,000 years. Great that it's still being used for entertainment.

What's cool about this amphitheater is that it is still in use today, 2000 years after its construction. Every week there is a performance from courses camarguaises (where they don't kill the bulls) to shows of Arlesian traditions to real bullfights (where the bull is killed).

We visited Arles on our Viking cruise. The first day we went to Arles and began a walking tour of the city. We walked up to the Roman amphatheatre which has been restored and is still in use. It is very impressive. It is still used for concerts and bull fights.

I was in Arles in December 2012 (part of a 6 country Eurorail jaunt). Friends had told me this town is a horrible tourist town in the summer, but December was wonderful there; although 2C, it was clear blue skies the whole time. And you can buy a combination ticket for the

The fact this huge amphitheatre survives from Roman times is amazing, but it's hard to imagine what it must have been like as the whole thing is covered in scaffolding and wooden seating. Probably a great place to watch something (they do gladiator fights!) but as a tourist
A beautiful specimen, the center of life in today's Arles. This is the core. We rented a house across the street. What a view! Everything in antique Arles emanates from here.

This amphitheater dates to Roman times. It is well preserved and maintained and used as an events'- bull fighting ring PLUS concert venue. From the top of the stadium there are some beautiful views of the Rhone River. Based on the design, it is probably an excellent concert
For 12 euros, you can see 4 monuments (all within a short walk from each other) and 1 museum. All impressive ruins. In-between, try one or two cafes.

Actively used today, but built by Romans about the same time as the famous Roman Coliseum. They still host bull fights - can't say I'm excited about that. But the history and architecture was fun to see. Try to avoid hot weather when seeing this.

This a well preserved Roman amphitheater still in use for bullfights and other events. I bought a ticket to visit on my own and wandered around inside. Nearby is a Roman theater, also still used today.

Overall this place was interesting - somewhat because it has the Roman history to it, but is still used for current events. You can learn some construction info, use your imagination about past events, and see one of the better preserved amphitheaters of Europe.

This is a well preserved piece of Roman architecturen not as grand as the Coliseum in Rome, but similar the one in Verona, Italy. It stands as the centre piece of the Old Walled Town and is surrounded by sidewalk cafe's and souvenir shops. Another ancient building of interest,

Arles has a few examples of Roman construction, all of which are easy to find and visit. This Amphitheatre is still used today. To my best of recollection, there were no private tours for it, however, there were many panels with pictures and information about the time and the
This roman coliseum has been very well restored and is a fine example of Roman architecture. There are bull races on certain nights for those interested.

We visited about 30 minutes before closing and got this a little cheaper which was a bonus. We made it for the last session of gladiator combat which really helped to bring the history of the place back to life. It would have been nice to see an opera or the bull running to
les Arenes is a beautiful Romain monument very well preserved. I attended 2 parties of "Les rencontres d'Arles" the bigger and older festival of photography of the world. It was a great experience
This was the third Roman amphitheater I have toured, including the Coliseum in Rome, and it was outstanding. The students learned a great deal and it is in great shape!

What a wonderful experience this was, you could feel the history throughout the Amphitheatre as you walked round, make your way to the top seats for a outstanding view and photo's. This is great value at 9 euro's. We went back the following night for the Bull races, this is

This was an extraordinary and unmissable experience. We were privileged to watch a modern display of extraordinary skill by the gardians (wranglers) of the white horses and black bulls of the Camargue, in an arena built by the Romans 2000 years ago for their own barbaric games.

Forget Rome, here you will have a real alternative. This will be a real Roman experience: you will feel it closer, without the enormous tourist mass, and with a real quiet and laid down ambient. Just great.

We attended a bull game in the Arles Amphitheater. it was an amazing experience to be able to attend an event in a 2000 year old building, walking through the tunnel-like corridors and coming out under a round arch into the bright sunshine to sit on a stone seat and watch the

Fabulous experience. Tickets alsogive you entry to 2 other Roman sites in Nimes. This is the best-preserved of the 2 amphitheatres (the other is in Arles) in the region. You can climb high up and imagine the Roman gladiators etc in the arena. The 360o view from the top, of the

As this coliseum is still working, it provides a more complete and cared for version than Rome in a way. Smaller of course and less well labelled/explained than its famous cousin... But great to climb around and explore

One of the main reasons many people visit Arles other than Art and worth doing so. The Roman history of Arles is so interesting and this is so worth a visit. Can get quite busy so get there before the hordes!
Amazingly preserved Roman arena. Went to see the bull games and back for night time photo op. A close walk from anywhere in Arles.

The amphitheatre is a must see in Arles. Definitely the highlight of the trip and the site Arles is most famous for, it is well restored and huge. There is a tower to the side providing great views over the whole city. It is open roofed so a good idea to go on a sunny day!
This is a beautiful area to explore. There are fabulous Roman ruins that are partially restored as well as piles of rubble excavated from the site. In total we spent less than an hour here.

It is always amazing to experience a historical site such as this. The Amphitheatre is structurally beautiful and it was wonderful to be able to sit on the stone steps and walk on the walls and imagine what it was like so many years ago. I highly recommend visiting this site

My family visited in July. Go early as it gets too hot in the middle of the day. The Nimes/ Orange combined ticket offers excellent value for money. The view in the theatre was a bit spoils because they were setting up for a concert by David Gilmore - so it was full of staging

Must say after the visit of Arena of Nimes i had doubt to go in. But this actually was much better to see. It remind me to be in Barcelona. Really lovely to be there and great view when going to the tower. Is a good price so if you there don't miss it.

This is a must see. To walk within the walls of so much history is breathtaking. Explore, take pictures and look out for the cat. We think he is a Lion come back to haunt the walls and keep visitors in line.

The amphitheater is no doubt the main attraction in Arles. Given its age and the fact that it is still being used regularly it's in amazing condition. If you have any kind of interest in history it's a must see. Admission fee is pretty modest at 9 euro. If you're planning to see

It was an amazing experience to sit on stone steps that Romans sat on 2000 years ago. And it was even more exciting to watch the bull games in the arena. I loved Arles and this was a very Arlesian thing to do.
We came by to visit the building only. However, on the same day, they made some kind of bull fight - with no fighting :-) Arles in general is very lovely.

We went to Arles,you can't fail to miss the amphitheatre. As per a previous post,we walked around it and peered inside. As mentioned previously,the walk around it was impressive enough without the need to go inside,you can see lots of scaffolding holding the new seats over the

Pros: • Very inexpensive (9 euros for adults and 7 euros for students) • Free to roam basically everywhere and every level in the structure yourself • The ability to still watch bull fights and horse shows every week at once again an inexpensive price • Open to all ages •
The amphitheatre is Arles is typical for the era. We've seen plenty and this one is very well preserved and still in use. That's why they have installed modern benches over the the Roman stone.

Wandering thru town after dinner upon arrival, with plans to visit the arena the following day. Well, it seemed they were having a grand spectacle with free entry that night, so we stumbled in and grabbed a seat. Good deal, quite the local patrimoine going on. Unfortunately, Mr.

This was the reason we went to Arles for the day. Although there was a modern stage inside when we visited it is well worth it if you're into history. Parking was fun, but once we found a spot it wasn't the extortionate rates we would expect in the UK. All in all, I'd
Not quite as big or smart as its neighbour in Nimes but beautiful none these. Parked in the middle of the old town.

The Arles Amphitheatre is a beautiful scene to see. We went there by train from Marseilles. It did not cost much and duration was not too long either, I just do not remember the times unfortunately. But it was a pleasant journey. The arena is only a few minutes walk from the
This place is wonderful from outside but since there is built a modern stage inside there is no reason to go inside. But it is worth to walk around it and see it from outside.

The Arles Amphitheatre (Coliseum) is another beautiful legacy of the Roman ingenuity and engineering skills. Quite well preserved - despite the encroaching city buildings - it's still used for shows. Although more modest than its more famous sibling in Rome, it serves to show
Arles has a history of being a Roman town in the 123 BC and there are numerous Roman buildings one of which is the Amphitheatre. Not to be missed, this place is a nice place to visit when in Arles.

Enjoyed our look around this amphitheatre, probably preferred it to Nimes but not sure quite why! Annoyingly, like all the attractions like this in Provence, they have scaffolding and staging in the middle so ruins the atmosphere somewhat! Good views from the top and good amount
Somewhat more authentic than Nîmes despite not being as well preserved. Nice views of the city from the higher seats. Informative audiotour.
It was amazing to walk amongst a Roman built arena. It is over 1700 years old and a person could just imagine being there with chariot races happening. Highly recommend.

Walking through the Ies Arenes, one will notice the difference between the original structures and the newly restored ones which stood side-by-side. The amphitheater represented the Roman occupation in this area and the historic life-style it left behind. Therefore visiting

This is an excellently restored colosseum and captures remarkable features from its time of build 45BC !!!! ...... It was great from a historical perspective .... BUT WE GOT REALLY LUCKY ....whilst we were there we got to witness simulated gladiator battles (minus the thumb

The day we visited the arena was hosting a local pageant and admission was free. We were able to see some local color and didn't need to pay for admission. We didn't get to go in the tower, but could still get a good view.
We stumbled on a bull fight... What an experience... Very impressing as is but with a full crowed and a unique bull fifth show... A MUST
This Amphitheatre has a cousin in Nimes but this is smaller. It doesn't have cover from the sun but is very beautiful and a great place for learning

Although labelled as an Amphitheatre this is an arena (the theatre is next door). I find that many of the reviews on Trip Advisor confuse the two. I always find these interesting but preferred the one in Nimes. Visit it by all means if you have bought the museums pass.

We discovered that in Arles ancient does not mean no longer used. Both the Classical Theater and this Amphitheatre are still used on a regular basis. During our time in Arles the Classical Theater was closed for rehearsal and here at the Amphitheatre they were setting up for a

We bought a 3 in 1 museum pass and visited the amphitheatre as one of the three. We were able to go straight through and view this wonderful ancient structure. It is great to see that it is still being used for the purpose it was created.
It is a Roman coliseum but there's only so much you can do there. Walk the corridors, peek at the arena. The shops and cafes near it are great though.

I loved walking around the amphitheatre. So atmospheric and only spoiled by the ticket clerk refusing to refund our ticket to change it into a multi-attraction ticket, which she should have mentioned to us before purchase. The arched promenade was gorgeous and very
Great amphitheatre. Good views from the top. Quite atmospheric. Plenty of places to clamber around. No cafe, but toilets.

I had great expectation of this Amphitheater but it was very disappointing. He admission charge was €8, and they didn't give you any literature or audio guide like others Roman sites in Provence. To my opinion that the Amphitheater in Nimes is far better. I would not even

My husband and kids love Roman ruins and really enjoyed this monument. Things to climb on and easy to walk around. It would have been nice if there was more information in English, and more information all round actually. We went on Saturday when there is a big market on the

The Arenes de Frejus is definitely worth a visit. The outside walls are from around 40 BC and give you a real sense of how the Frejusians lived during that period. You can imagine the bullfights, judgements for beheadings, parties and theatre that took place in each century. It
Went on weekday, but could only see from outside since it was rented for a rehearsal of sorts. Bummer. Not coliseum in Rome but pretty neat nevertheless. Def a touch of history.

Always love seeing Roman ruins in various parts of Europe. This particular arena was no exception. We purchased a Liberte Pass for entry into the Amphitheater and several other sights for 11 Euro per person. It was a great deal and made visting this site, and others in Arles,
is worth even the travel of long distances: spectacular and fascinating monument, very well preserved and almost looks 'like new' with its 60 arcs

We walked up narrow streets alive with history to this remaining ampitheatre....the majority of its structure intact restored and in use today for different productions. The design and acoustics of this design allow for many succressful stagings of all kinds of theatres and
It would be wonderful to see the bullfights here. I think they are few and far between. Other than that there is little to see.

Although parts of this have been reconstructed, there is enough of the Roman original left to see how impressive the original was. You can walk all round the different areas and get a feel for what it was originally like. There was a school group being shown how to be

The feeling of the age of the structure is spoiled by the modern seating. I guess they need to hold events inside to help pay for the restoration. On a positive note, our 8 euro admission also let us into the theatre.

Amazing to think that the core of the arena is truly ancient. Brilliant views of Arles and the Rhine on the high tower. Make sure to walk the hallways under the stadium. There are some very interesting discoveries to be had.

text.wiki:
The University of Montpellier (French: Université de Montpellier) is a French public research university in Montpellier in south-east of France. Established in 1292, the University of Montpellier is one of the oldest universities in the world.
The university was split into three universities (the University of Montpellier 1, the University of Montpellier 2 and the Paul Valéry University Montpellier 3) for 45 years from 1970 until 2015 when it was subsequently reunified by the merger of the two former, with the latter, now named Paul Valéry University Montpellier, remaining a separate entity.


== History ==

The university is considerably older than its formal founding date, associated with a papal bill issued by Pope Nicholas IV in 1289, combining all the centuries-old schools into a university.It is not known exactly when the schools of liberal arts were founded that developed into the Montpellier faculty of arts; it may be that they were a direct continuation of the Gallo-Roman schools that gathered around masters of rhetoric. The school of law was founded by Placentinus, from the school of law at Bologna, who came to Montpellier in 1160, taught there during two different periods, and died there in 1192. The faculty of law has had a long career. Professors from Montpellier were prominent in the drafting of the Napoleonic Code, the civil code by which France is still guided and a foundation for modern law codes wherever Napoleonic influence extended. The faculty of law was reorganized in 1998.
The prestigious school of medicine was founded perhaps by people trained in the Spanish medical schools; it is certain that, as early as 1137, there were excellent physicians at Montpellier University. It is the world's oldest medical school still in operation. The school of medicine owed its success to a policy of the Guilhem lords of Montpellier, by which any licensed physician might lecture there: with no fixed limit to the number of teachers, lectures multiplied, thus providing a great choice of teachers coming from all around the Mediterranean region (Guilhem VIII act of January 1181). The statutes given in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad von Urach, legate of Pope Honorius III, which were confirmed and extended in 1240, placed this school under the direction of the Bishop of Maguelonne, but the school enjoyed a great deal of de facto autonomy.
The school was famous for arguing in the fourteenth century that the Black Death was caused by a miasma entering the opening of the body's pores, citing theories developed by Galen. Doctors educated at Montpellier advocated against bathing because they claimed bathing opened the body's pores, making one more susceptible to the bubonic plague.In 1529, after some years as an apothecary, Nostradamus entered the University of Montpellier to study for a doctorate in medicine. He was expelled shortly afterwards when it was discovered that he had been an apothecary, a "manual trade" expressly banned by the university statutes.[8] The expulsion document (BIU Montpellier, Register S 2 folio 87) still exists in the faculty library. Rabelais took his medical degree at Montpellier, and his portrait hangs among the gallery of professors.
The Jardin des plantes de Montpellier, founded in 1593, is the oldest botanical garden in France. It was in this school that the biological theory of vitalism, elaborated by Barthez (1734–1806), had its origin. The French Revolution did not interrupt the existence of the faculty of medicine. The Benedictine monastery that had been converted into the bishop's palace, was given to house the medical school in 1795. A gallery devoted to the portraits of professors since 1239 contains one of Rabelais.
The school of theology had its origins in lectures in the convents: St. Anthony of Padua, Raymundus Lullus, and the Dominican Bernard de la Treille all lectured. Two letters of King John II prove that a faculty of theology existed at Montpellier independently of the convents, in January 1350. By a Bull of 17 December 1421, Pope Martin V granted canonical institution to this faculty and united it closely with the faculty of law.
In the 16th century the local triumph of Calvinism interrupted the somewhat somnolent Catholic school of theology, which was reinstated in 1622; but the rivalries of Dominicans and Jesuits interfered seriously with the prosperity of the faculty, which disappeared at the Revolution. In better days, among Montpellier's illustrious pupils of law were Petrarch, who spent four years at Montpellier, and among its lecturers were William of Nogaret, chancellor to Philip IV, Guillaume de Grimoard, afterwards Pope Urban V, and Pedro de Luna, afterwards antipope Benedict XIII.
Like all other provincial universities of France, that of Montpellier was suppressed at the outbreak of the French Revolution in 1793. The faculties of science and of letters were re-established in 1810; that of law in 1880. The university of Montpellier was officially re-organised in 1969, on the aftermath of May 1968 and the students' revolt all over the country. It was split into its successor institutions the University of Montpellier 1 (comprising the former faculties of medicine, law, and economy), University of Montpellier 2 (science and technology) and University of Montpellier 3 (social sciences, humanities and liberal arts).
On 1 January 2015, the University of Montpellier 1 and the University of Montpellier 2 merged to form the newly recreated University of Montpellier. Meanwhile, the Paul Valéry University Montpellier 3, now only Paul Valéry, remains a separate institution.


== Rankings ==
Overall Ranking
University of Montpellier secured 55th and 16th places in the world and Europe, respectively, in Reuters - The World's Most Innovative Universities 2018. It is also ranked among the top 200 universities in the Academic Ranking of World Universities 2019.Law
University of Montpellier undergraduate law program is ranked 6th of France by Eduniversal, with 3 stars (2016/17).Ecology
University of Montpellier was ranked 1st in the world in Ecology in the subject rankings of Academic Ranking of World Universities 2018.


== Notable alumni ==
Francesco Petrarca, Italian scholar and poet in Renaissance Italy, widely considered to be the founder of Humanism
Amalricus Augerii, 14th-century church-historian
François Rabelais, humanist writer
Alexander Grothendieck, 20th-century mathematician, Fields Medal winner
Enver Hoxha, communist dictator of Albania from 1944 until his death in 1985
Taha Hussein, was one of the most influential 20th-century Egyptian writers
Albert Zafy, President of Madagascar 1993–96
Khieu Samphan, Head of State of Cambodia under Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge regime
Nostradamus, a French apothecary and reputed seer, who is best known for his book Les Propheties
Raja Rao, one of three primary Indian Writers in English, awarded the Neustadt Prize in 1988
Adamantios Korais, a Greek scholar  and a major figure in the Greek Enlightenment
Sahle-Work Zewde, is an Ethiopian politician and diplomat who is the current President of Ethiopia, the first woman to hold the office
Mohed Altrad, a Syrian-born French billionaire businessman, rugby chairman and writer
Andreas Vesalius , Wrote the "Corporis Fabrica Libri Septem", the first Medical Anatomy book based on human anatomy rather than animal anatomy.

text.wiki:
Montpellier (UK: , US: , French: [mɔ̃pəlje, -pɛl-] (listen); Occitan: Montpelhièr [mumpeˈʎɛ]) is a city near the south coast of France on the Mediterranean Sea. It is the capital of the Hérault department. It is located in the Occitanie region. In 2016, 607,896 people lived in the urban area and 281,613 in the city itself. Nearly one third of the population are students from three universities and from three higher education institutions that are outside the university framework in the city.


== Status ==
Montpellier is the third-largest French city on the Mediterranean coast after Marseille and Nice. It is the 7th-largest city of France, and is also the fastest-growing city in the country over the past 25 years.


== History ==


=== Medieval period ===
In the Early Middle Ages, the nearby episcopal town of Maguelone was the major settlement in the area, but raids by pirates encouraged settlement a little further inland. Montpellier, first mentioned in a document of 985, was founded under a local feudal dynasty, the Guilhem, who combined two hamlets and built a castle and walls around the united settlement. The name is from medieval Latin mons pislerius, referring to the woad used for dyeing locally. The two surviving towers of the city walls, the Tour des Pins and the Tour de la Babotte, were built later, around the year 1200. Montpellier came to prominence in the 12th century—as a trading centre, with trading links across the Mediterranean world, and a rich Jewish cultural life that flourished within traditions of tolerance of Muslims, Jews and Cathars—and later of its Protestants. William VIII of Montpellier gave freedom for all to teach medicine in Montpellier in 1180. The city's faculties of law and medicine were established in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad of Urach, legate of Pope Honorius III; the medicine faculty has, over the centuries, been one of the major centres for the teaching of medicine in Europe. This era marked the high point of Montpellier's prominence. The city became a possession of the Kings of Aragon in 1204 by the marriage of Peter II of Aragon with Marie of Montpellier, who was given the city and its dependencies as part of her dowry.
Montpellier gained a charter in 1204 when Peter and Marie confirmed the city's traditional freedoms and granted the city the right to choose twelve governing consuls annually. Under the Kings of Aragon, Montpellier became a very important city, a major economic centre and the primary centre for the spice trade in the Kingdom of France. It was the second or third most important city of France at that time, with some 40,000 inhabitants before the Black Death. Montpellier remained a possession of the crown of Aragon until it passed to James III of Majorca, who sold the city to the French king Philip VI in 1349, to raise funds for his ongoing struggle with Peter IV of Aragon. In the 14th century, Pope Urban VIII gave Montpellier a new monastery dedicated to Saint Peter, noteworthy for the very unusual porch of its chapel, supported by two high, somewhat rocket-like towers. With its importance steadily increasing, the city finally gained a bishop, who moved from Maguelone in 1536, and the huge monastery chapel became a cathedral. In 1432, Jacques Cœur established himself in the city and it became an important economic centre, until 1481 when Marseilles overshadowed it in this role.
From the middle of the 14th century until the French Revolution (1789), Montpellier was part of the province of Languedoc.


=== After the Reformation ===
At the time of the Reformation in the 16th century, many of the inhabitants of Montpellier became Protestants (or Huguenots as they were known in France) and the city became a stronghold of Protestant resistance to the Catholic French crown. In 1622, King Louis XIII besieged the city which surrendered after a two-month siege (Siege of Montpellier), afterwards building the Citadel of Montpellier to secure it. Louis XIV made Montpellier capital of Bas Languedoc, and the town started to embellish itself, by building the Promenade du Peyrou, the Esplanade and a large number of houses in the historic centre. After the French Revolution, the city became the capital of the much smaller Hérault.


=== Modern history ===

During the 19th century the city thrived on the wine culture that it was able to produce due to the abundance of sun throughout the year. The wine consumption in France allowed Montpellier's citizens to become very wealthy until in the 1890s a fungal disease had spread amongst the vineyards and the people were no longer able to grow the grapes needed for wine. After this the city had grown because it welcomed immigrants from Algeria and other parts of northern Africa after Algeria's independence from France. In the 21st century Montpellier is between France's number 7th and 8th largest city. The city had another influx in population more recently, largely due to the student population, who make up about one-third of Montpellier's population. The school of medicine kickstarted the city's thriving university culture, though many other universities have been well established there. The coastal city also has such developments as the Corum and the Antigone that have attracted an increasing number of students.


=== Lords of Montpellier ===

William I of Montpellier (died 1019)
William II of Montpellier (died 1025)
William III of Montpellier (died 1058)
William IV of Montpellier (died 1068)
William V of Montpellier (died 1121)
William VI of Montpellier (died 1149)
William VII of Montpellier (died 1179)
William VIII of Montpellier (died 1202)
Marie of Montpellier (died 1213)
and King Peter II of Aragon (died 1213)
James I of Aragon (died 1276)
James II of Majorca (died 1311)
Sancho of Majorca (died 1324)
James III of Majorca (died 1349)


== Geography ==

The city is situated on hilly ground 10 km (6 mi) inland from the Mediterranean coast, on the River Lez. The name of the city, which was originally Monspessulanus, is said to have stood for mont pelé (the naked hill, because the vegetation was poor), or le mont de la colline (the mount of the hill)
Montpellier is located 170 km (106 mi) from Marseille, 242 km (150 mi) from Toulouse, and 748 km (465 mi) from Paris.
Montpellier's highest point is the Place du Peyrou, at an altitude of 57 m (187 ft). The city is built on two hills, Montpellier and Montpelliéret, thus some of its streets have great differences of altitude. Some of its streets are also very narrow and old, which gives it a more intimate feel.


=== Climate ===
Montpellier has a Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csa), with mild, damp winters, and hot, rather dry summers. The monthly mean ranges from 7.2 °C (45.0 °F) in January to 24.1 °C (75.4 °F) in July. Precipitation is around 630 millimetres (24.8 in), and is greatest in fall and winter, but not absent in summer, either. Extreme temperatures have ranged from −17.8 °C (−0.04 °F) recorded on 5 February 1963 and up to 43.5 °C (110.3 °F) on 28 June 2019.


== Neighbourhoods ==

Since 2001, Montpellier has been divided into seven official neighbourhoods, themselves divided into sub-neighbourhoods. Each of them possesses a neighbourhood council.

Montpellier-centre : historical centre (Écusson), Comédie, Gares, Faubourg Boutonnet, Saint-Charles, Faubourg Saint-Jaume, Peyrou, Les Arceaux, Figuerolles, Faubourg du Courreau, Gambetta, Clémenceau, Méditerranée, boulevard de Strasbourg, Le Triangle, Polygone, Antigone, Nouveau-Monde, Parc à Ballons, Les Aubes, Les Beaux-Arts, Saint-Lazare.
Croix-d'Argent : avenue de Toulouse, Croix d'Argent, Mas Drevon, Tastavin, Lemasson, Garosud, Mas de Bagnères, Mas Nouguier, les Sabines, Lepic, Pas du Loup, Estanove, les Bouisses, Val-de-Crozes, Bagatelle.
Les Cévennes : Les Cévennes, Alco, Le Petit Bard, Pergola, Saint-Clément, Clémentville, Las Rebès, La Chamberte, La Martelle, Montpellier-Village, Les Grisettes, Les Grèzes.
Mosson : La Mosson, Celleneuve, La Paillade, les Hauts-de-Massane, Le Grand-Mail, Les Tritons.
Hôpitaux-Facultés : Malbosc, Saint-Priest, Euromédecine, Zolad, Plan des 4 Seigneurs, Hôpitaux, IUT, Père Soulas, Universités, Vert-Bois, Hauts de Boutonnet, Aiguelongue, Justice, Parc zoologique de Lunaret, Agropolis.
Port-Marianne : La Pompignane, Richter, Millénaire, Jacques Cœur, Consuls de Mer, Grammont, Odysseum, Montaubérou, La Méjanelle, Cambacérès.
Prés d'Arènes : Les Prés d'Arènes, Avenue de Palavas, La Rauze, Tournezy, Saint-Martin, Les Aiguerelles, Pont-Trinquat, Cité Mion.


== Population ==
The whole metropolitan area had a population of 510,400 in 2006. And in a study made by INSEE from 2007 to 2012 Montpellier saw the strongest population growth of France's main communes (+1.1%), ahead of Paris and Lyon. In 2011, the estimated population of the metropolitan area was 561,326.For most of its history, and even today, Montpellier is known for its significant Spanish population, heritage and influence. Montpellier also houses important Moroccan, Algerian, and Italian communities.


== Heraldry ==


== Sights ==

The main focus point of the city is the Place de la Comédie, with the Opéra Comédie built in 1888.
The Musée Fabre.
In the historic centre, a significant number of hôtels particuliers (i.e. mansions) can be found. The majority of the buildings of the historic centre of Montpellier (called the Écusson because its shape is roughly that of an escutcheon) have medieval roots and were modified between the 16th and the 18th centuries. Some buildings, along Rue Foch and the Place de la Comédie, were built in the 19th century.
The Rue du Bras de Fer (Iron Arm Street) is very typical of the medieval Montpellier.
The mikve, ritual Jewish bath, dates back to the 12th century and is one of very few in Europe.
The Jardin des plantes de Montpellier—oldest botanical garden in France, founded in 1593
The La Serre Amazonienne, a tropical rain forest greenhouse
The 14th-century Saint Pierre Cathedral
The Porte du Peyrou, a triumphal arch built at the end of the 17th century, and the Place Royal du Peyrou built in the 17th century, are the highest point of the Ecusson.
The Tour des Pins, the only remaining of 25 towers of the city medieval walls, built around 1200.
The Tour de la Babotte, a medieval tower which was modified in the 18th century to house an observatory.
The Saint Clément Aqueduct, built in the 18th century.
The Antigone District and other housing projects have been designed by the architect Ricardo Bofill from Catalonia, Spain
A number of châteaux, so-called follies, built by wealthy merchants surround the city
Nearly 80 private mansions were built in the city from the 17th to 19th century, and some of their interior courtyards are open


== Education ==


=== History ===
The University of Montpellier is one of the oldest in the world, founded in 1160, and having been granted a charter in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad von Urach and confirmed by Pope Nicholas IV in a papal bull of 1289. It was suppressed during the French Revolution but was
re-established in 1896.
It is not known exactly at what date the schools of literature were founded which developed into the Montpellier faculty of arts; it may be that they were a direct continuation of the Gallo-Roman schools. The school of law was founded by Placentinus, a doctor from Bologna University, who came to Montpellier in 1160, taught there during two different periods, and died there in 1192. The school of medicine was founded perhaps by a graduate of the Muslim Spain medical schools; it is certain that, as early as 1137, there were excellent physicians at Montpellier. The statutes given in 1220 by Cardinal Conrad, legate of Honorius III, which were completed in 1240 by Pierre de Conques, placed this school under the direction of the Bishop of Maguelonne. Pope Nicholas IV issued a Bull in 1289, combining all the schools into a university, which was placed under the direction of the bishop, but which in fact enjoyed a large measure of autonomy.
Theology was at first taught in the convents, in which St. Anthony of Padua, Raymond Lullus, and the Dominican Bernard de la Treille lectured. Two letters of King John prove that a faculty of theology existed at Montpellier independently of the convents, in January 1350. By a Bull of 17 December 1421, Martin V granted canonical institution to this faculty and united it closely with the faculty of law. In the 16th century the faculty of theology disappeared for a time, when Calvinism, in the reign of Henry II of France, held complete possession of the city. It resumed its functions after Louis XIII had reestablished the royal power at Montpellier in 1622; but the rivalries of Dominicans and Jesuits interfered seriously with the prosperity of the faculty, which disappeared at the Revolution. The faculty numbered among its illustrious pupils of law Petrarch, who spent four years at Montpellier, and among its lecturers Guillaume de Nogaret, chancellor to Philip the Fair, Guillaume de Grimoard, afterwards pope under the name of Urban V, and Pedro de Luna, antipope as Benedict XIII. But after the 15th century this faculty fell into decay, as did also the faculty of arts, although for a time, under Henry IV of France, the latter faculty had among its lecturers Casaubon.
The Montpellier school of medicine owed its success to the ruling of the Guilhems, lords of the town, by which any licensed physician might lecture there; there was no fixed limit to the number of teachers, lectures were multiplied, and there was a great wealth of teaching. Rabelais took his medical degrees at Montpellier. It was in this school that the biological theory of vitalism, elaborated by Barthez (1734–1806), had its origin. The French Revolution did not interrupt the existence of the faculty of medicine.
The faculties of science and of letters were re-established in 1810; that of law in 1880. It was on the occasion of the sixth centenary of the university, celebrated in 1889, that the Government of France announced its intention—which has since been realized—of reorganizing the provincial universities in France.

== Transport ==

Montpellier is served by railway, including TGV highspeed trains. Montpellier's main railway station is Saint-Roch. There are plans to construct a high-speed railway linking Nîmes and Montpellier with the LGV Méditerranée.

The Montpellier – Méditerranée Airport is located in the area of Fréjorgues, in the town of Mauguio, southeast of Montpellier.
The Transports de l'agglomération de Montpellier (TaM) manages the city's public transportation, including its 56-kilometre (35 mi) tramway network consisting of four lines and several parking facilities. Line 1 runs from Mosson in the west to Odysseum in the east. Line 2 runs from Jacou in the northeast to St. Jean-de-Vedas in the southwest. Line 3 and Line 4 opened in April 2012. Line 3, which is 22.4-kilometre (13.9 mi) long, links Juvignac and Perols with a branch to Lattes and serves 32 stations. Line 4 circles the centre and serves as a connector line between the various arms of tram system. They intersect at Gare St. Roch station, Rives du Lez and Corum.
The TaM also manages the large bike sharing scheme Vélomagg', started in June 2007, comprising 1200 bicycles and 50 stations.


== Sport ==

Montpellier was the finish of Stage 11 and the departure of Stage 12 in the 2007 Tour de France.  It was also the finish of Stage 11 and the departure of Stage 12 in the 2016 edition. The city is home to a variety of professional sports teams:

Montpellier Hérault Rugby, of the Top 14 who play rugby union formerly at the Stade Sabathé and now at the Altrad Stadium. In the 2010/2011 season, the team made it to the Top 14 Final against the Stade Toulousain.
Montpellier HSC of Ligue 1 who play association football at the Stade de la Mosson. MHSC became French Champions on 20 May 2012.
Montpellier Red Devils who play rugby league in Elite 1 division at the Stade Sabathé
Montpellier Agglomération Handball are a team handball club playing in the French National League.
Montpellier Vipers of France's Division 1 ice hockey Federation, play at the Patinoire de l'Agglomération de Montpellier at Odysseum
Montpellier Water Polo play in the National League and European Cup competitions.
Barracudas de Montpellier is a baseball club, and competes in Division Élite, a French top level baseball league.Montpellier was one of the hosts of the FIBA EuroBasket 2015.
The city is home to the Open Sud de France tennis tournament since 2010, and will host the XXXI World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championship.
The main athletics stadium is the Philippidès Stadium, which is owned by the University of Montpellier.


== Culture ==
The city is a centre for cultural events as there are many students. Montpellier has two large concert venues: Le Zenith Sud (7.000 seats) and L'Arena (14.000 seats). Le Corum cultural and conference centre contains three auditoriums.

The Festival de Radio France et Montpellier is a summer festival of opera and other music held in Montpellier. The festival concentrates on classical music and jazz with about 150 events, including opera, concerts, films, and talks. Most of these events are free and are held in the historic courtyards of the city or in the modern concert halls of Le Corum near historical city center.
The annual Cinemed, the International Mediterranean Film Festival Montpellier, held in the fall, is the second largest French film festival after the Cannes Film Festival. Held since 1979, it offers screenings of over 200 long and short films, documentaries, animated films, trailers, and a special program of student films. Other events include panel discussions, exhibitions, and gatherings. Venues include Le Corum and cinema halls.

== Other locations named after Montpellier ==
"Montpellier" is used as the name of other towns and streets in as many as four continents. Many places in England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland carry the name Montpellier. Often they are in resort locations claiming some of the healthy attributes for which the French city was renowned in earlier centuries. The variant spelling "Montpelier" is common, and is of quite early provenance. Brewer uses that spelling. The first example was the early 19th-century suburb of Montpelier in Brighton.The capital of the American state of Vermont was named Montpelier because of the high regard in which the Americans held the French who had aided their Revolutionary War against the British. Several other American cities are also named Montpelier.
Places named Montpellier/Montpelier are also found in Australia, Canada, South Africa, and the Caribbean.

Worth a visit - good permanent collection focussed on local artists, and fascinating special El Greco exhibition. 10 euro entry meant visitor numbers were reasonable and noise levels low, and it was possible to see everything without jostling elbows with others

As other review reports, this is an interesting museum. Views are amazing. Restaurant is well done. Miro exhibit there now - summer 2014 - is excellent.
A breathtaking view over the sea and THE cimetery . Very interesting paintings by local artists and temporary exhibitions. Next door restaurant is worth stopping after the visit or before.

contemporary art floor was rubbish but I enjoyed the rest of the works and the gallery itself is a nice venue

We really enjoyed our visit to both the gallery and the restaurant, with fantastic views of the Mediterannean. What a great location, with wonderful a wonderful art collection in a light and airy gallery!
very fine art gallery, beautiful modern paintings, one room dedicated to Valéry, a couple of rooms of local painters - really enjoyable afternoon

This gallery always punches above its weight and exhibitions during the summer are invariably interesting. Well worth a visit.

Compact visiting collection of Impressionists well worth an hour or so and much easier to digest than the major national museums. The permanent exhibition is fairly small but has good local atmosphere (and some seriously weird contemporary stuff).

This is a wonderful museum and they always have very interesting visiting exhibits; we've been going at least annually for about a decade and look forward each time we return. Also, enjoy the view after you've parked.
I have been here three times - always great exhibitions on expressionism (Raoul Dufy, Auguste Chabaud, ...) - great setting. Just the car parking is a bit small and wild.
