Viewed the Chabaud exhibition with friends. I had never heard of the artist previously so this for me was a new and exciting experience. I would recommend this exhibition highly
The permanent collection is well worth visiting again & again & the special exhibitions they put on are well curated & easy to access

When we visited the Chabaud exhibit was on display and while I'm not a big fan of Chabaud, I did like the permanent collection which was impressive for such a small museum. All artwork is by French artists and covers most genres - it's quite beautiful and worth a visit.

There is a temporary exhibition by Chabaud, fauvism and impressionism, and the decorative installations outside garden is also nice. On your walk up to the museum, you can see the fantastic view of Sete. Very nice

Glorious exhibition in the (fairrly) rrecently refurbished Paul Valery. Curious choice of wall colour but a superb exhibition by a superb curator who has moved fom Lodeve to Sète. There is a professionalism in theis musée that marks it above many of it's contemporaries.
This art museum is excellent for such a small town. There are local artists on the bottom floor and exhibitions on the second. The paintings are from the period 1840 - 1940 or so.
Best view in Sete and a good place for a coffee or meal. Permanent collection good - touring some really good works

text.wiki:
Marseillan is a commune in the Hérault department in southern France.
It lies some 50 km (31 mi) west of Montpellier.
Marseillan sits on a large lagoon, the Étang de Thau, and is the southern entreport for the Canal du Midi.
The centre of the village lies within the lines of the old walls. There is a hotel and a number of cafes and restaurants. Marseillan Plage is a purpose-built holiday resort on the Mediterranean, some 3 km (1.9 mi) from Marseillan Ville.
The port is a protected heritage site, and the altar and organ in the church are also listed. There has been virtually no new building in the heart of the village since the 17th century, and many of the houses date from the twelfth century.
Until 1970 the vineyards came to the main boulevards built outside the line of the walls around 1870. Since then the population has grown from around 3,000 throughout the last 200 years to over 10,000 in 2010. This does not include those who have bought houses and villas in Marseillan but use them only as holiday homes. Expectation is that the population will top 14,000 by 2015.


== History ==
There is dispute as to who exactly founded the village. Marseille claims that honour, largely due to the similarity between the names of the two towns. But both names are derived from the Greco/Phoenician Massaliotes who extended trading routes from the eastern Mediterranean.
The Massaliotes certainly founded Marseille around 600 BC and, shortly after, Agde. Thus, Agde is said to be the second oldest town in France. The foundation of Marseillan, however, is less clear. As Agde is only 8 km (5.0 mi) away it seems most likely that the Agatois were the founders. In any case, the origins of all three places lie with the Greco/Phoenicians. And, either way, Marseillan is one of the oldest villages in France.
The Romans established the port, and with the Via Domitia running close they also established a rest and recreation centre. Many legionnaires took their discharge at Marseillan, and with it a grant of land - on which they grew vines.


== Economy ==
Marseillan's economy is founded on fish, wines, trade and visitors. This has always been so because from its foundation Marseillan has been a major trading centre, a port and a stopping-off point for travellers.


=== Trade ===
When the village was founded there was a clean inland waterway paralleling the Mediterranean - described as "une petite mer intérieure et tranquille". Thus sailors could make their way in safety from the Rhône to Marseillan. Thus from the beginning Marseillan was a trading post.
Over the years this waterway silted up, forming the series of Etangs, the largest of which being the Étang de Thau, but then the Canal du Midi opened and Marseillan, as the Entreport, was a major beneficiary.
It follows that from the very early days Marseillan had the four bases of trade that exist today.
Much later Marseillan was linked by the Rhone-Sète Canal to the river Rhone and by the Canal du Midi to Toulouse and thence to the Atlantic at Bordeaux. Its location means that Marseillan became a crucial link in the network of canals that still encircle France.


=== Fishing ===
The Étang de Thau is shallow, with a bottom of foot-deep mud. The conditions are perfect for shellfish and 18 different sorts are fished from the Etang. As the water is Class A they can be eaten straightaway. Most notable are the oysters and the mussels.
‘Bouziques’ oysters, from the Étang, provide about 10% of France's annual oyster consumption. They are cultivated from oyster tables with one farmer able to bring up a family comfortably on the production from two tables.
Mussels are taken from the rich band of mussel-friendly water that runs along the Mediterranean coast from Marseillan to Marseilles. Marseillan fishers work 3 km from the shore, with the Agatois in larger boats fishing further out.
Sea fish are also caught in the Étang. They are carried in by the force of the current generated by the narrowness of the canals. (There are no tides on the Mediterranean, but the mass of water shifts dependent on the prevailing wind. Thus the level of the Étang is constantly shifting.)


=== Wines ===
Table wines are produced, with the most acceptable being Picpoul de Pinet - an attractive white wine with a slight green tint and a little sparkle. About a million bottles annually are produced by the cave co-operative.
The Noilly Prat company came to Marseillan in 1853, and is still producing its vermouths on the same site. Mr Noilly had created the vermouth in Lyon in 1813. His son, with an English partner (Mr Prat), came to Marseillan to commercialise their product because the local wines were very suitable and the climate was ideal.


=== Visitors ===
Always a stopping point on the long routes along the Mediterranean shore Marseillan has provided travellers with a welcome since the village was founded.
Today much of the village's prosperity comes from the summer visitors: holidaymakers in Marseillan Plage, day visitors to Marseillan Ville, houseboat visitors from the Canal du Midi and owners of holiday homes.
To some degree even those northerners who have settled permanently are visitors. Certainly they make a substantial contribution to the local economy.


== Population ==


== Buildings ==


=== Fortification ===
The old village has remained unchanged through the centuries, and today's village is almost identical in shape to the one known in the Middle Ages. This is because Marseillan was a fortified village until late in the 18th century.
From the second century BC Marseillan was protected by earthworks, but by Roman times it had a timber stockade. This was sufficient until Simon de Montfort and his army passed through during the Cathar Crusade. New stone fortifications then replaced the timber.
The Château sat foursquare in the centre of the village, behind its own walls, whilst the village walls were themselves four-and-a-half metres high. There were four gates, six watchtowers and the village was moated.


=== Habitation ===
Most of the village houses are back-to-back. Typically they are of three storeys. A stable on the ground floor, living space on the first and fodder stored on the second. The rear rooms are without light or ventilation. With the houses protected from mosquitoes by zinc screens, and in the heat of the Midi, it must have been barely tolerable even to people born into the village. Today the mosquitoes have been eradicated, but it is still uncomfortable in the rear rooms in high summer.
Most houses in the old village are small or very small. Their staircases are narrow, and twisty.
Some larger homes were owned by the entrepreneurs who typically moved out of the village and into the main boulevards from around 1870.
These new large homes were also working houses. Maisons de maître and maisons de vigneron have no particular architectural style, but they are all of two or three storeys, with the ground floor a working area. All have double doors to allow entry to the horse-drawn transport. Sometimes there was direct access from the rear of the house to the vineyards. Almost always there was a small kitchen garden and a pump.


=== Construction ===
Construction is typically of ‘torchis’ bricks made from sun dried clay and straw. There are no foundations because a metre down is the water table. Every house in Marseillan has rising damp. This is actually essential to the survival of the houses since they have to be built to withstand the climate changes.
In the winter the ground expands, and in summer it contracts. The houses have to be able to flex to cope with these changes. So lime mixed with sand from the beach was used rather than cement (which hardly flexes), and cracks in the façade are normal. Some houses are built from soft limestone which was taken from the vineyards. Basalt, hard volcanic stone, is commonly used for door and window frames.
It is not uncommon to find that houses have been adapted and renovated over the ages and many have several different building materials co-existing within the one building. Renovation is not a modern initiative, Marseillan houses have been renovated and adapted since they were first built.
Today bathrooms have been added, but piped water and sanitation have only been in the village since 1958. Most houses had their private pump, however.


== Climate ==
Marseillan enjoys an equable climate. Sheltered by the mountains of the Massif Central the weather systems from the north are seldom a problem. Marseillan has some 300 sunny days a year, and ground frosts (at worst) in mid-winter. From time-to-time a little snow falls, but this only dusts the ground and is gone by mid-day. Marseillanais make day trips into the mountains to experience snowballing and to make snowmen.
The prevailing winds are from the south-west, and south. Marseillan receives the hot winds from the Sahara but does not suffer the pink sand that those winds carry out to sea. The Mistral blows down the Rhone valley and, although a northerly wind is sometimes referred to as a “mistral” it has none of the severity nor persistence of the true version.


== Of interest ==
The Marseillanais have always taken their time over decisions, but have still been leaders in many areas. A hospital existed in 1,100 and is still treating patients today (having had several homes over the years!). The maire (mayor) was elected in the village 200 years before this was required by Royal decree. Public schooling started in the mid-18th century. The school was co-educational from 1870 (but not the classes). The oldest stone Marianne in France was erected in 1878, following a wooden bust created in 1876. Marseillan voted to become secular some 10 years before the country as a whole. Women were allowed into one designated cafe from 1870 — again earlier than most other towns and villages.


== Personalities ==
Achille Maffre de Baugé  (1855-1928), poet
Marcel Barral (known as Marcel Viala) (1912-1997, poet
Pierre Deley, one of the first pilots of the Aéropostale and grandnephew of Général Roques
General Pierre Auguste Roques (28 December 1856 - 1920), founder of French military aviation, Minister of War 1916. Originally buried in Marseillan, his remains now lie in the Hôtel des Invalides, Paris
Christian Beullac, (29 November 1923 - 16 June 1986), politician
Jean-Pierre Hortoland (born 28 May 1947), rugby union player


== See also ==
Communes of the Hérault department


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website (in French)
Official website (in English)
Culture & history (in English)
[1] (in French) Website of panoramic photos of Marseillan and its region

The tour at Noilly Prat was very interesting and included the tasting of different varieties. Delicious products are available at attached shop and cocktails at the bar. It took us 3 attempts until we could attend a tour in German though because we received wrong information

Amazing experience for those who want to understand how vermouth is produced. Our guide, Pascal, was friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. And, of course, the vermouth is exceptional.

We visited during one of the English Speaking tours of which there are 1 or 2 daily depending on the season. The tour took about 45 minutes and is really interesting - great to see such an old process still in use in an original premises. Samples at the end were worth the price

Very informative tour of the NP cellar and old part of the factory. Now part of Bacardi it keeps its unique family feel,producing vermouth still using some traditional methods. English tours at 10.30 and 3pm . Tasting four different NPs and opportunity to taste more cocktails
You cannot visit without trying an original dry gin martini... also cater for kids with sorbets and soft drinks... well worth a visit every time we are in the area

An hour well spent. The tour guide was very knowledgable and interesting. Tasted all the types of Noilly Prat and given a further one of our choice. Very interesting and highly recommended.

I've drink my share of Noilly Pratt vermouth in the past but in truth had no idea how it was made, or where.....such an informative tour, about the right length, very reasonably priced and enough details to keep the most curious of minds satisfied. All the staff we encountered

Lovely staff who served us whilst we bought a bottle, but we were too late at 1830 on a Sunday in June. Beautiful inside courtyard and extremely knowledgable staff

We really enjoyed learning how Noilly Prat is made from an English-speaking guide. It's very interesting seeing the various stages of the process and the tasting at the end is fun. The buildings are historic, with a lovely courtyard in the middle that has benches to sit on in
lovely in Quiet port a, very interesting to visit whistst looking round in marseillan lovely port of marseillan

What can I say that has not been mentioned in the hundreds of previous reviews. This is a fascinating and educational tour learning about the history and manufacturing process. What I can emphasize is the courtesy and warmth of the staff! Olivia in public relations who helped me

The tour is very interesting and ends with a tasting of all four kinds of Noilly Prat. The location is worth a visit and the tour guide spoke excellent English, and answered all questions in a lively manner. Not to be missed when in Marseillan.

A very friendly place to visit whilst looking round this lovely port of Marseillan, guided tours which show you the making and maturing of the Nolly Prat, a hidden secret with its barrel filled court yard just meters from the sea. A good tasting session follows and the Ambre

What a fun and interesting tour we had. Our guide, Pascal, was very entertaining and knowledgeable about the process of making Vermouth. The tasting at the end of the tour was especially enlightening for someone like me who doesn't drink this stuff regularly. I can highly

Our knowledgable and charming English speaking guide Antonia, gave us a fabulous insight into the history and making of the different vermouths whilst we were shown around the interesting exhibits. The finale was when Antonia expertly presented the Ambre, Rouge and Original Dry
Excellent taste of wine and choclate Nice tour around the winery and a good taste of wines afterwards.

Wonderful learning about the history of this delicious aperitif. You'll be able to sample all four of their drinks, plus have the option of mixing your own drink after. The "Amber" is only available here, so stock up. Lovely spot, fun tour and reasonable price.

While in Marseillan, a visit to the French vermouth factory of Noilly Prat is a must. We arrived shortly after ten and were welcomed by a lovely classy lady. We only had to wait about five minutes for a short guided tour (in French) for which no reservation was needed. Our
Excellent tour, go and see this place... I am not going to spoil it by saying everything, but I would recomend a visit its ony a few quid to see the open cellar, the produce to but is also lovely.

English speaking guide available and it was an interesting tour of the history, making of vermouth, and then the tasting and where in the world the products are available..
Antonia from New Zealand gave us a fascinating tour of the site. We had never appreciated before how good Noilly Prat really is.
On a very hot day what better thing to do is find a cool place and learn the history of Noilly Prat. The tasting session afterwards was great and don't forget to pick up your free cocktail leaflet!

We were lucky enough to have a private tour of the site - and what a treasure it is! Well worth the 7.50 euros for a genuine slice of French wine/vermouth making history. Highly recommend a visit!
This winery is a great place to visit. They have certain tours each day that are in English which is v useful. The staff are very informative and welcoming. The tasting at the end is a must 😀🍸

Following trip advisor recommendations we visited Noilly Prat. There was only one other person on the English tour apart from our family of 5. The tour was very informative with plenty of opportunities to ask questions. We enjoyed smelling all the herbs used in making the
I had no idea of the complexities in the production and artistry required to create Vermouth. The guided tour is well worth the money and culminates with a fantastic tasting!

This is a genuinely very interesting historic tour - its not a winery - there's a real (secret) recipe needed to make this vermouth - the trip is an absolute must Recommendation - pay extra for the one hour trip - don't go for the express tour
We visited here several years ago on our first visit to the area. We were taken on the tour in a small group by a lady who spoke perfect English. An interesting diversion for an hour or two.
I have been drinking Noilly Prat for years but never knew how it was produced so took their very inofrmative and fun tour. To be recommended!

Noliiy Prat (rhymes with 'cat') came to Marseillan in the mid 1800s because of the quality of the wine and access to the Canal du Midi. The tour shows one exactly how Noilly Prat is made (but they won't give away which of the herbs they show you actually go into the product).
Very interesting place to visit and where you will learn about vermouth for sure. A stop for sure...

Not something we'd drink much of ourselves, but an interesting place to drop into after lunch in Marseillan. The young man (Jonathon?) who explained the process of producing the liquor to us was very knowledgeable and had excellent English. Worth a few minutes of your time.
I love Noilly Prat and seeing how it is made and where it comes from was really special. Must purchase some Noilly Ambre as this us the only place you can get it. A lovely respite in touring

Interesting tour of the factory, seeing how Noilly Prat is made and hearing some of the history. Tasting of all three varieties was available at the end, and it tasted all the better for knowing a bit about how it was made.

We had a really fascinating tour (in english) from the Noilly Prat guide Nathalie. Much better than any other winery or cognac place we've visited. She was so jolly, enthusiastic, and well informed, we felt we were almost visiting her house!. The place itself smells exotically

Marseillan is a lovely port at the end of the Canal du Midi and the star attraction is the Noilly Prat factory. The iconic vermouth is produced here and there is a short tour and degustation of the three styles of vermouth made available most days. Well worth 4 euros.

A really fascinating insight into the process of making Vermouth. We joined a French speaking tour and, despite understanding very little, still very much enjoyed the visit. The tasting at the end was great and the products available to buy of the highest quality. Best to check

Arrived well before 14h30, the official time of the afternoon tour.When the office did open, we were told that the tour had already started - somehow inadvertently we had missed their booking system. We paid 8 euros 20 for two adults even though the price quoted at the entrance

Visited the Noilly Prat 'factory' - by accident. Was vaguely aware of the drink but now know all about it thanks to a 'private' evening tour with the cellar master. A limited number of people - ten I think - get to do a personal tour with the cellar master and hear all about
Interesting and informative tour, great value. The tour guides are friendly and welcoming. The tour was entertaining. Excellent value.

Wonderful time spent at noilly Prat. Very gentle informative way to spend the morning. My two teenagers enjoyed it. The tour (excellent guide Lisa) was in French and English and explained the production of noily Prat, followed by a tasting. No hard sell, however we did buy some

Took the tour in English this afternoon. Already knew how this vermouth is produced but wanted to see it first hand. It was very fascinating seeing how they masserate the herbs and spices in the wine to impart the different flavours. Enjoyed the inevitable tasting at the end

Seen it on TV and interesting to see for real. They make vermouth for others as well as themselves and "cook" their wine in the sun with a load of botanicals whilst periodically setting the sprinklers on the barrels. Mad but it clearly works!

We did the cellar master tour and whilst the cellar master did not speak English a friendly we had a very nice translator who came with the tour. We also got tastings half way round and at the end with the end ones being In our own VIP room. Highly recommended and the amber

When you're in Marseillan don't miss out on a tour of this winery. It's an interesting tour covering the how, what and where of the production process. Including the range of herbs added to this delicious Vermouth. Inevitably the tour ends with a tasting. In addition to the

Lovely staff who are so willing to please we joined a French tour but the young lady who was our guide was able to answer our questions in English. As soon as you get into the cellar the aroma was wonderful. The tour lasts for about half an hour and well worth the 4euro cost.

An organised tour round an aperitif blending site, with unique methods. Well organised, well presented and interesting. Recommend that you try the Ambré version of Noilly Prat. Staff very friendly and helpful.

We stayed in Marseillan for four days and ended with a tour if Noilly Prat. The first impression is the wonderful aroma, which changes as the tour progresses to different areas. The small enthusiastic team brought the whole place to life and the tasting at the end of the tour
Fascinating to visit this establishment, and also to taste the Ambre in addition to the well-known red & white varieties. Flavoured ice cream & chocolates are also very tempting!

The tour of the distillery is fairly short but interesting and well run and include a tasting session at the end. Entry price is reasonable (4E?) Some tours are in English. There is a nice little cafe in the courtyard but there are also some very good restaurants in the area,

We visited last week while on holiday. At Noilly Prat they make vermouth, a wine mixed with a secret blend of herbs and spices. The Museum tour was in English and very interesting, our tour guide was very entertaining in her delivery. At the end of the tour the was a tasting of

Interesting little tour - Kelly knows her stuff from the history to the wine-making process and was a charming host. Enjoyed the tasting - even my son who usually only drinks beer was impressed. Good way to spend an hour especially when it is very hot outside!

We enjoyed the tour and learned a lot about the Making of Noilly Prat. All very professional and well put together. The tasting was good too - tasting and comparing the three blends of Noilly Plat is something you can't do anywhere else. We purchased a bottle of the Amber

It just takes an hour to do this tour and you will be told a lot about the history of a worldfamous product by a bilingual guide (some are even trilingual). Now you understand why James Bond was so fond of his cocktails! The tasting of the 3 different types of vermouth is
A very interesting visit around Marseillan's most famous landmark. This is an excellent place to spend a few hours learning about the part this famous building played in Marseillan's recent history
Very professional tour from bilingual guide, interesting history. Not too long, tasting included in the price.
try to get a private tour with one the three men who know the "secret". This was informative and fun

There's a lovely smell in the air in the chai with 000's of litres of Noilly Prat slowly maturing. Interesting tour, about 30 mins, completely in French though they do have an English tour so check first. 4.10 euros each for adults. Usually easy to park close by. Tasting at the
Very well organised tour with a chance to taste the product. Situated in a very pretty port with good choice of restaurants.
If you are looking for something to do in Marseillan, then the Noilly Prat museum offers a good diversion for an hour or so.

Fun to have a look round at the big barrels and herbs & spices used, see the outside ageing and hear all about the angel's share - unfortunately, I'm just not a big fan of the drink itself so husband got the benefit of double helpings at the tasting!

So James Bond is wrong; the perfect martini is (as well as being made with Noilly Prat) should be stirred not shaken. Just one nugget we picked up from an interesting and enjoyable tour of Chais Noilly Prat which ended with a tasting of the three different vermouths. The tour

Produced in Marseillan this liqueur like most, is very much a personal taste. It does however work very well as a cooking ingredient with the predominately seafood local specialities, particularly in a creamy leek sace with scallops(cocquille St. Jacques)
We had a nice tour of the Noilly Prat plant as well as a tasting. The Vermouth has a fascinating history and for martini buffs well worth the time!

If you are in and around Marseillan there is a great tour around the winery that produces the famous vermouth Noilly Prat. The building is on the pretty quay overlooking the port and the tour is not expensive and includes a tasting and there is a good shop where one can purchase
Well worth a visit; the guided tour is very good and afterwards there is the opportunity to taste and buy the products
Very friendly and helpful English tour. Well worth the price and the time.
Very friendly and welcoming, knowledgable guides. Generous wine-tasting.

Really worth a visit, even if only for the free aperitif at the end see how a famous f-drink is made from oxidizes wine - a magic formula and many years of experience - the site of a field af barrels festering in the sunshine is worth it by itself

Very interesting tour. Check tour times before you commit as not all are in English

The tour of the Noilly Prat distillery is one of the best tours I've ever been on. It lasts about an hour (not too long!) and it is very interesting to see every part of the distilling process. The guides speak very good English and are happy to answer questions. The tour has a
